110030.question: I've created a song that was supposed to mean one thing, and it's really great when heard in that way with that perspective. However there's another obvious way to see / feel it that causes it to give off really bad vibes. After catching those vibes when listening to a mixdown afterwards, it almost felt like I accidentally released demons during recording. But then I remembered the original intent. Basically the lyrics are kind of a joke and on their own are harmless, but there's still a well-intended normal base meaning I had while creating the song. I arranged and recorded everything fully seriously given that base meaning. Every word I sang was me singing about that base meaning and meaning it, and every piece of instrumentation was realizing the base meaning. However the joke lyrics taken at face value with the intentional arrangement and recordings create a weird vibe. I'm still going to release it, but it's an odd situation. I've learned that when you're making music you're kinda playing with fire because you're really playing with the human experience. Have you ever created unintentional vibes from a song or video?

110038.question: how do you know when a song is on the right track? i keep noodling on a keyboard and making words and sounds and chords that feel kinda random - never really knowing what progression truly feels like a song to start working on
110038.answer: what works for me is to separate this into separate job positions. when i'm idea generating, i'm never in the same job position as someone who's actually gonna work on the song. it allows the idea generation to be carefree and optimistic. so when i'm thinking of ideas, i add things to the list that i think 'could' work. And the truth is, any idea can be made great if it's handled well. so i have the confidence to know that. so i add things to the list, generously. Then, at a different time, in a different job position, i have methods of selection where i 'select' which item in the list is going to be chosen to get finished, and produced. Or there's also another step/job in between that which is to just select things and just develop them a tiny little bit. So this means your initial idea is free to be almost nothing. Just a title.... just a couple of notes.... just a groove... maybe just an image, ... something that is almost nothing, but it's just enough for the next department to grab onto and turn it into something slightly more, for next time

110039.question: Is Fm7 Fm7/9 F#maj7 Emaj7 (uh ah oh eh) Bbm7 Cm7 Bb/D B/D# Dbmaj7 (the melody is drifting into the future) correct? I love playing the song on the guitar and with my voice, And those are the chords I use o that 3rd chorus...

110064.question: do you ever come up with one part of a song and then you can't come up with anything else that goes with that part how do you get out of it ( i tried imagining what would happen after that part but all i can imagine is a loop ) does it get easier to come up with more stuff over time, as you finish more songs
110064.answer: can't Yet. That reminds me of how it's currently February, 2023, and we can't seem to get to any month beyond that all the information is relevant. For example: you say you tend to hear it as a loop. Ok, so, ..... is that good or bad? Is there any reason why you feel it should not be a loop? Do you not like the way it feels as a loop? Many great songs indeed are viable as a loop. So i'd say, be open to the possibility of a loop (unless you hate it.) Actually i should be more specific.... when you say loop, are you saying absolutely everything repeats? or are you saying like just the chords and certain things loop? Many songs have a loop but they still use different melodies for cho and verse, or something. On the other hand, there's probably other songs that actually just about use the same melody for both...... anyway, my point is, all the information you can gather from your impressions after the run through is valid, and should be considered. So in this case, your impression is that it seems to loop. Consider the possibility of making it loop. If not the whole thing exactly, then consider the possibility of keeping the same form / chords and then just raising or lowering the energy. in most loop based songs, the raise and lower of energy is the bread and butter that takes you from verse to chorus to verse you might get some more wisdom over time, but i feel like nothing is ever going to fully shield you from this dread zone of 'trying too hard' and 'thinking too much.' And i'm not blaming you. The reason you are thinking and trying is because you really care about this damn thing, and rightfully so. But the weird thing about music is it really clams up when people start trying and thinking a lot. It wants to find you, so be aware that it will find you. you just don't always get to decide when. But until then, just recognize all the information you are getting, which, in this case, is that it seems to require a loop. That's actually a very powerful piece of information. it rules out a lot of things

As soon as you find some more concrete direction and tasks to deal with, i think this current worry will float away

110070.question: What inspired you to make "meet me in september"
110070.answer: i was on a schedule where a song (with video) had to be done, so that is the reason that *a* song/video (didn't have to be that one) got done at that time, and the reason that particular one got picked was because it was the only one i wanted to do at that time. i recall going through the entire list and not finding anything i wanted, but i'd accidentally skipped that one, so that one literally turned up in the last place i could have looked. That being said, it had no title or lyric when i selected it. So the reason it became 'meet me in septemter' is because that is the best line i could come up with for the first/title line. Going back to before it was selected, the reason i came up with that idea in the first place is because that's part of my job as a songwriter/producer. gotta come up with the ideas. that's pretty much the first step. I'm sure i came up with at least a dozen different other ideas on the same day. i tend to do them in batches unless a freebie drops on my head in a dream or something

110085.question: someone told me "i am lying" and then asked me to say if it was true or not what do you think
110085.answer: i'd say it alternates over time, at a rate of one switch per the smallest possible time-unit. which is currently thought to be something called the Planck time. So, in other words, every 0.0000000000000000000000000000000000000000000539 seconds the statement should switch from true to false, or from false to true, because that would be the soonest possible time that anything could change, and intrinsically the statement is always due to invert.

110156.question: If you wrote la de da de da de da de day oh in 2012, then why didn't you make it until 2018?

110160.question: ok long question incoming. so recently i've been trying to use numbers to notate chords instead of just using specific chord symbols to the key (like 1m7 instead of Cm7). it seems like a good idea to get a good understanding of chord progressions and also to understand the relationships and how to transpose easily and quickly. i started doing this by using the real book and just translating them on a piece of paper. but i ran into this problem again and again and i really am stuck on it for some reason. Ok, so say we're in Cmin. an Abmaj7 chord appears. if the Cmin chord is the 1m, would the Abmaj7 be the 6maj7 (the 6th note of a C minor scale) or b6maj7 (the flat 6th of a C major scale)? i'm probably overthinking this but the b6maj7 feels better to me
110160.answer: b6 would be the answer here. that's just how people do it. there is logic to calling it 6 but it's just not what you're gonna see people doing out in the world. the convention, for the most part, is to refer to the Ab chord as b6 in the key of C or Cmin. and 6maj would be Amaj which you'd be certainly not likely to see in Cmin but for example you'd be likely to see 6dom7 in the key of C, with a likelyhood of 2min (Dmin) after it, etc

110202.question: what the fuck is a time signature and how do i read and write their expressions
110202.answer: i guess 90% of the game here is realizing that the most common time signature is 4/4, also sometimes written as 'C'. This means there are 4 beats per bar. if you already have an understanding of beats and bars, then i can go ahead and explain how the number system works (which, again, is really only important about 10% of the time, because most of the time it's just 4/4 and you don't have to worry about it). But if you don't know what beats and bars are, then i'd have to start there. There is a mathematical explanation of how the time-signature system works, and it's good to understand that, but, there's also some ways that it's used that are more like a societal standard and not so much just math. The way the number system is supposed to work is, the top number is how many beats there are in a bar (4) and the bottom number is what note gets one beat. So for example, 4/4 (written on paper with the first number directly on top of the second number) means there's 4 beats per bar, and a quarter note gets one beat. 7/8 should mean there are 7 beats per bar, and an 8th note gets one beat. But actually, the second half of those statements is kind of shaky, because, for example, in a time signature like 6/8, which is extremely common, it would be like "6 beats per bar, and an 8th note gets 1 beat" but in many cases 6/8 is really felt more like 2 beats per bar and a dotted quarter gets one beat (which is mathematically equivalent, but no one writes dots in timesignatures). But, one thing that remains certain, it still correctly describes the bar length. So it would always be accurate to say, for 6/8 for example, there are 6 8th notes per bar. In 4/4, there are 4 quarter notes per bar. in 11/16, there are 11 16th notes per bar. This way of describing it will always be correct. in 3/4, there are 3 quarter notes per bar. in 2/2, there are two half notes per bar

110238.question: what were the origins of "where I've been"?
110238.answer: during an idea generating session on apr 11, 2019, i came up with the chord figure and melody for the verse. during a songwork session on apr 20, 2021, i got the lyrics to the first stanza. in late august 2022, i was searching through the list to find the next song to select for song/video production (due sept 13), and "where i've been" seemed to be a highly favored choice at that time, but i instead decided to actually use no selection, and just start writing a video (to possibly lead into a song, or maybe not) without any song selection. But i guess "where i've been" was still at the forefront of my mind, so i ended up launching into it within the first few seconds of the dialogue. It was actually my goal to really write something that combined song and non-song in a more 50/50 balanced way, but then there's also generally a desire to make the song playable as a song on its own, outside the video. As i continued writing, i actually broke out of the song and back into more dialogue after the first stanza. And that was pretty fun and cool, but i knew that wouldn't work for the song-only version. So then i found myself in a position where i was writing 2 different versions of this whole thing, in parallel: one version which breaks in and out of song, and another version that stays in the song once the song starts. And pretty quickly i realized that that would be way too confusing. So i just kept it in song without breaking it. So my goal of really mixing the song and non-song 50/50 turned out to be a failure, this time around. and the "where i've been" song ended up taking over, with no return to diaglogue, for the rest of the video. Also, the goodbyes section has a completely alternately written version, which still ends with the last line as is (where i was / wasn't). I ended up completely rewriting that section because the first version felt like it had too strong a similarity to the 'bring me down / pick me up' section of ground plane

110254.question: For the middle section of "if the world doesn't end " where ut goes "its good its bad" I understand that it starts on a gmin7 then I think moves to a F#maj7/Ab on "been like that". Also for the " it's wrong its right " am I right in saying it goes from Cmin7add9 to some variation on Bbmin7? 110254.answer: 'rearrangement' is Ab7sus4 (or Gb/Ab). I still don't have a reliable technique for finding an intro to a song which seems to have been born without an intro. But maybe the best way is to write a scene for the song to spring from. that method might be the most powerful

110265.question: Is there a name for when you substitute a min7 chord for a dom7 chord? Like, if you're in C major and you do an D7, E7, or A7 (instead of Dm7, Em7, Am7)? It doesn't feel like a "modal interchange" or anything fancy like that because the melody will still feel very much like plain old C major. And sometimes too you'll even have a C7 (particularly before going to the F), but it doesn't feel like you're in C mixolydian or anything like that. < I can think of a lot of songs (especially common in old timey songs) that have a chord pattern like: C C7 F F#dim C A7 D7 G7 C A7 D7 G7 C But it still feels and sounds like C major even though most of those chords aren't in the key. Would you still consider that to be in C major? Maybe the key of a song is totally based on the melody and not the harmony?
110265.answer: indeed, i call that 'normal' that one you just mentioned reminds me of a door handle that turns sideways when the door opens. even though the handle is normally not in that position, the sideways position IS actually a normal position for the purpose of opening the door. not only normal, but powerful. a real door opener, that C7 (to F) yep even with no melody, the chord sequence you are describing is certainly in the key of C. .....It's as if we're trying to figure out whether a donut with sprinkles is still a donut, even though the sprinkles are not made of donut. indeed it is still a donut, especially considering the decorative materials in question are in fact very standard classic materials, used in the very standard classic way. and no one in history has ever dared to call such a donut a non-donut

110271.question: So for the middle section on "if the world doesn't end " again, at " when one world ends" I think its Ebmin7, but for " comes alive " my ear wants to hear an Fmin7 but I'm hearing a C in the bass and the second inversion of that Fmin7 doesn't sound quite right there when I play it with the song so I'm not sure. But I think for "comes along for the " you switch to an f major which in my mind functioned as a 5 to modulate to Bb but then u did an interrupted cadence to gmin7 on "ride" which I loved. Then on "Change you're mind" I'm hearing a Dmaj7/E then an Abmaj7 then it goes back to the sus2sus4 voicing on the E on "stay for a while". Then I'm not too sure but I think I've got the chords for the bit that follows which leads back to the main verse: Amaj7 Abmaj7 Dmaj7/E Ab Db I was also wondering why there were so many major 7th chords with their 2nds in the bass in this middle section, it's a very specific sound that's amazing to listen to and I don't remember hearing it in many of you're previous songs , correct me if I'm wrong tho.
110271.answer: Db in the bass it's Dbmaj7 that's like F7sus4 or Fsus4, pretending as if it's going to Bbmin yep don't know where you got that right there i like them, except i don't think of it as 1 over 2, it usually feels more like 4 over 5 to me. i use it all the time. it's really not that far off from D/E, or E9sus4. which i'd use in the key of A. i also use them in more 'orphaned' key contexts. it's a nice way to land in a new key on that chord as if it's the 5. happens a lot near the end of bridges, if we've launched around through some keys, it's a good landing point for a 5 chord in a new key (or even, back to the original key, if it works out that way.) But it also is just a good textural modal vamp, in which case it would feel more like a 1 chord in mixolydian

110276.question: what is the inspiration for la de da de da de da de day oh? i feel like it has a lot more hidden meaning than some of your other songs.
110276.answer: the verse part was written somewhere in early 2009 when i was feeling like there's too many zillions of ways to do songwriting and i haven't even discovered most of them yet. so i was feeling like i don't have enough time to do stuff. the "be like you" is just a lyric swap i did when i picked it up to work on it in sept 2012. it just felt more 'in the pocket' musically. and 'believe them too' was from the same 2012 session, to match 'be like you' in that same pocket. prior to the sept 2012 session, i only had up to the end of the first pre-chorus, which is about 'wanting to write a song'. and it was all cued up to hit the chorus. so 'la de da de da' is like, that's the sound of a song being written. i got the entire chorus written on that session, and i was pleased with the results. that possibly made the song feel like it was up on a pedestal (afraid to touch it because i like it too much, i'm afraid i'll ruin it). and it stayed right there for years, with nothing beyond the first cho. it finally was up for selection in october 2017 when i was brave enough, and it was picked by the final random selection among about 27 other semi-final choices. i almost changed my mind the next day because i was still afraid to ruin it, but then i suddenly tricked myself into imagining the second verse, then the first 3 lines of the second verse came very quickly and then i was confident in the song selection. i continued the writing until the end, according to my standard songwriting practices and procedures

110277.question: so i understand how to figure out the chords for so-called 'pop' songs but when it comes to jazzy/whatever songs where there's like 1 chord a syllable and the chords get really complicated i have trouble figuring out what's what, have no idea what key everything is in, etc. how do i approach this?
110277.answer: i'm not sure what kind of songs you're talking about, but if it's too overwhelming then you might have to stay with something a little bit simpler until you have a little more experience. but if you are feeling bold you can just go in and start trying to make sense of it. if it makes less than .01% sense at the moment, then you should stay with simpler things for a little while longer. but if you're getting at least 25% sense out of it, then it's probably worth the endeavor. and then come back to it again later when you have more experience and it will probably be even clearer then

After said break the harmonies in the verses became more ambiguous, especially after "I'm scared " and in "at the corner store" where the whole of the verse is just a whole lotta Bsus4 . And in 987 where there's the maj7 slash chords and such. Might just be my imagination so point me out if I'm wrong. What I was wondering is, was this shift in the fundamentals of the music part of the conscious decision to change your style as of when you decided to master 3d animating during your break?
110395.answer: i don't think your hypothesis is correct, but if it were that would be a huge coincidence because those songs were not all written in the order they were released. for example, here comes the sun was mostly written as it is now, by 2012 i'm a princess was recorded in 2019. and the musical shift was a production shift, not a writing shift, and that occured in the summer of 2021

110427.question: What do you think about the famous adage/attitude that goes, "Art is never completed, only abandoned. Except Star Wars. Star Wars was complete when I saw it as a child in the 80s."?
110427.answer: that reminds me of another famous adage: "All art is based on how far you can push the technology. So, the more facile, the more fluid the technology, the easier it is to actually do your art. And, in this particular case, I looked at it, and I said, there's a lot of things that I think could be improved here. Primarily editing, which is the thing I was the most interested in. And special effects, which is the other thing I was interested in. And it wasn't really until I did Star Wars that we started to deal with some digital technology. It was very early on in the process of making films using computers. And we had to build some special purpose computers for Star Wars."

110502.question: i never really tried to comprehend music as a kid so i developed absolute pitch and relied solely on that and now i still have bad relative pitch. for example in choir if the sheet music is in a different key from what we're actually singing in, i get really slow at reading the music. how can i stop thinking about absolute pitch to get more fluent at relative pitch which i know is the actually important one? also i hate when people think having absolute pitch equals talent, but then i'm still happy that i get to annoy my friends by naming the pitch of the microwave or the car honk or something,
110502.answer: i've never been in your exact situation, but i think there's good news here. absolute pitch is just about impossible to develop after age 6. relative pitch, however, does not seem to have this hard limitation. so at least you don't have to worry that you missed the bus entirely on this. here's a clever suggestion: what if you somehow sabotage all the absolute notions of the note letters. for example, just transpose your keyboard or something. here's an even better idea actually, ...... hold your left hand on the pitch bend wheel and move it back and forth in a very small range slowly, while playing things with your right hand. maybe linger around just one or 2 notes, and mash the pitch around, tenderly, as if trying to scratch an itch. follow what makes you feel good. this may unlock some doors for you

110573.question: i started making music while i was depressed, and the results are music that sounds like you would expect a depressed person to make (depressing), but i never released it. i feel better now, but i'm wondering if i should even bother finishing and releasing, or if i should just focus on making new music? finishing the old stuff will get stuff out faster, but working on new stuff will make my body of released work happier, on average (100%). i'm wondering how much that matters, or whether i am overthinking. idunno, maybe releasing the older stuff will bring me closure, and someone else catharsis. or maybe it will just make others share in my old uncomfy feelings that i've already worked so hard to shed, and heal from. some people only like music that sounds kinda dark, so releasing it might satisfy my libran desire to please everybody, by offering more variety............. do you have any thoughts/feelings about this? have you ever had a similar dilemma?
110573.answer: you can do both, if you can come up with a system you like, for organizing your time if you find yourself thinking about it, then you might as well figure out a clever system you can really get behind a number of different activities come to mind: you can write brand new things, and add them to the list. you can select older things on the list, and bring them to your modern writing table and learn how to work on them just as you would work on a modern song, fixing what you don't like. you can use your old songs as practice doing this. Another variation on these sorts of activities is: you can select something from the list and mark that as the item to be completed next (before any other) and then do whatever you gotta do to make it how you like it. The point is, there are so many different variations of workflows here, there's a lot of ways to get confused about which thing and which order you're working on things. I think as long as you're already thinking about this, it's worth really trying to craft a great system that you can really get excited about. in due time it can all be done, to the best of your liking

110683.question: here is a quandry: when i make art i usually will either make a still piece or music. recently i have been really wanting to combine the two and even make ANIMATIONS. So, i did. over spring break i spent the vast majority of my time on an animation and, (dutifully keeping track of the time using proven timekeeping methods) and i worked 27.59 hours to make a minute and a half little music video. this is obviously not sustainable when i have to deal with the rest of my life such as school and work (which i still had to deal with over spring break). and now, im trapped in a loop of indecision. i so desperately want to make still art and i can usually finish a piece in 5-6 hours or so which is extremely doable. yet, i also DESPERATELY SO BADLY want to make music, which if im making an instrumental will probably take me 15-20 hours and if im making something with vocals (dont even get me fucking started) it will probably take me 19 BILLION hours to do, not even on top of the fact that i would want some visuals to couple with either and that would take 15 more hours and, if i commit to something, i will have a final project like 2 months later because i have to work and go to school if i want to survive. anyways, sorry for rambling. i guess what im asking is, how can i make myself commit to something that feels fufilling, even if i know im just setting myself up to get trapped in the never ending project. sorry i hope that makes sense.
110683.answer: to this day i don't have the answers. but at least that makes it an exciting puzzle to solve. kind of like those puzzles on the frontier of science, that no one has solved

110693.answer: the verses are generally in blues form, in F. the bridge sections are mostly 2 5s, in F#. the outtro vamp is 4maj7, 3min7, 2min7, in F. but in each section there are a lot of specific moments with chords that only happen that one time. in addition, the actual chord voicings throughout the entire song are constructed in a very custom way, around the melody. to give a full moment by moment transcription of every harmonic occurence would be a sizeable project which would probably be irresponsible for me to do right now

110711.question: what is the hidden meaning behind "drum is shoe"
110711.answer: that's shown as an example of a "metaphor". in school, we were taught that a "simile" is a comparison that uses the word "like". but a "metaphor" is a comparison that does not use the word like. For example, a simile would be: "the drum is like a shoe". but a metaphor would be "the drum is a shoe". And i probably shortened it to "drum is shoe" to make it even easier to read, and to also allow space on the screen for the drum and the shoe

110713.question: Why was no brains written in F# major but performed in Bb major?
110713.answer: because when i wrote it, i was either not singing, or not singing at full volume. Before starting production, it's normal to do a 'key test', where i check how it feels to sing it at full volume, and find what key is best. that's when the production key of a song is determined, and it's all based on what key is best to sing it. it's common for the production key to be a few steps higher than the writing key, because as i'm writing i'm probably singing it quieter and not as intensely, therefore probably in a lower key for writing

110798.question: is there a secret to starting a project without immediately throwing away ideas? i've had trouble recently getting anything finished because i never seem to get started.

110825.question: Haiya bill. Just wondering in the melody, lyrics, chords, tempo, and roadmap, do you ever jot down ideas for specific instrumentation at certain points (brass hits, some guitar / synth figure, etc.) or do you tend to leave that for / change it up in production (examples appreciated)
110825.answer: yes, if it's something very important and prominant the first example that comes to mind, to explain this, is not my song, but it's a good example to explain it: if i were writing the song Africa (by Toto), i'd say the huge drum fill just before the chorus, that would be something written into the song. because that's something that takes the lead at that moment. if you were singing that song to a friend, you'd almost certainly have to sing that drum part there. it's a feature. but anyway, here are some examples from my own songs, of things that were written, or not: in "christmas isn't real", no specific instrument parts were written (other than the core elements you listed, as always) in "slow down", the melody riff in between stanzas near the end of the song, was written (it's just about the same as the vocal melody anyway, but it was written that that riff would occur there, instrumentally). The instrumental intro, however, was not written until production time. the instrumental break in the middle of the song was also not written aside from knowing that it would sync generally to the verse roadmap. in "i'm scared" the bassline in the title verses was written. Also the short instrumental riff that occurs midway through the chorus (fallin) section, was written. however i think there's a different variation the second time around which was not planned in the writing in "in california" the instrumental lines in the second prechorus were written. the horn stabs during that time, however, were not. The instrumental riffs behind the vocal during the chorus/bridge ('alright') sections, were not written in "i'm a princess", the instrumental melody in the chorus (which is the section that begins after 'about my world') was written. however, the much crazier melody in the final 8 bars was not written, aside from the road map and all the other core elements that you mentioned (as always) in "meet me in september", the instrumental (and vocal) riff after "celebrate"/"complicated" was written. also the instrumental fill between that section and the following verse, was written (both the first and second times that occurs). Also the climbing instrumental riff in the 3rd and 4th bars of one of the middle verses, was written the bell melody in the outtro of "movie star" was not written. also in the writing that was assumed to be a fade out in "i'm best friends with my own front door", in the break after the first verse-stanza, the instrumental repeat of the melody was written in "where i've been", the low-B bass rhythms near the end (during the 'good times' section) were written

110836.question: I have a chord progression that goes Gm7add 9 for a bar and a bit, then Gbmin7 to Fm7add9 for the next bar and a bit, then chromatically up again. I then do like a modulation to Cm where I go gm7, Ebmin7/Db, Cmin7add9, and that's a cool jazzy sound and all but it has the same sort of feel as what came before it so I'm asking where I should go harmonically in order to create a completely different sound as well as you do it in ur songs
110836.answer: you're just doing chords. and it sounds like you're trying to craft a song out of just chords. this may work, sort of, but, don't be surprised if you can't seem to really get anywhere strong. what i've found, when working, if i ever let 1 of these 3 elements (melody,chord,lyric) get too far ahead of the others, it very quickly gets very empty and the whole thing doesn't know or care where it's going, and hates itself, really. best case, all 3 elements are born at the exact same time. if 1 gets too far ahead, .. and you start to feel lost and confused, .... it's usually because 1 got too far ahead, so you gotta go back and get the whole vehicle involved. this ESPECIALLY becomes true at these junctures of "what happens next". that is exactly the time for the least used element to now have a say. that's how turns are made

110870.question: You said something interesting about how you can describe music as having three elements (melody, chord, lyric). At first I thought that including lyric in those three was a little silly but then I realized that that actually makes complete sense. Theres a very real extent to which the sound of a lyric or the context of a lyric affects the song itself or the way the song feels. Sometimes the best or most important part of a section is the thing that someone says during that section (e.g. all the soldiers surround me and make sure I'm lonely) Now, if one were to compose for a video game, that presents an issue. With a game, lyrics can be distracting, especially if they're in a language spoken by the person playing the game. So is music in games doomed to never reach the height of other types of music? I've also thought about using gibberish instead of real words in game songs, or just repeating one word over and over again (the Jet Set Radio soundtrack already does this).
110870.answer: there are other variations to this, but when it comes right down to it, music and non-music rely on each other. another example would be the underscore to a scene in a movie. no lyric, but instead we have characters and things happening. and again, in that case, all 3 should be considered together, because their reliance on each other is so intimate game music can reach higher heights than a lot of other music. because one of those core elements is actually YOU and what you are doing in the game. this is a perfect example of music and non-music enhancing each other intimately no reason it can't be lyricless, for a game or movie score. the game scene/action is what takes the focus, instead of the language in the lyric of a song

110942.question: How does one solve a tempo crisis?
110942.answer: after it's already happened, there's probably not much you can do. find a compromise tempo that's half way in between the right tempo for either part. but if it's too severe, you might look into some kind of tempo change in the song, but i think this usually doesn't work. and the 3rd option is to file the 2 sections separately into 2 different songs and continue with one of them. but to prevent a tempo crisis, get a metronome going early on. pause it to think, but when testing out ideas and doing runthroughs, always do it on click. can't go wrong that way

110949.question: what to so when you can't think of anything to write for your song? thanks
110949.answer: start writing down every experience you've had for the past 2 weeks, in list form. then, randomly select one of those experiences, and do a brainstorm about ways that could be a song. write down your findings next to that entry. then switch. randomly select another entry and brainstorm that, finding ways it could be a song. continue doing this and gradually each one gets pushed along and soon you will be finding actual lines to the song, etc

110998.question: I wrote a song a few weeks ago in three days and it came out really well, and I've been trying to write another one for some time now and I'm getting nowhere. how do you get into the proper mental state where your inspired enough to write music?
110998.answer: no one knows for sure. sometimes it comes to you when you least expect it. but what has helped for me is to separate it into 2 separate activities. Having the original idea, and then writing that idea to its completion. Those 2 jobs happen under completely different circumstances, and require completely different skill sets, and are best suited to totally different personalities. The original idea is like a magical bolt of lightning and it's almost impossible to fully control when or how it happens. but the other job, where you select one of those lightning bolts you got in the first job, and finish it -- that second job just requires patience and open-minded diligence

111103.question: can you explain your process for mentally figuring out the hex codes for colors again? i remember seeing your explanation for it once before a few years ago but have since forgotten it
111103.answer: it's R G B. the first 2 digits are red, the middle two are green, the last two are blue. And each of these 3 sections runs on a scale from 00 to FF, in hexidecimal that means 0 to 16, with 00 being the lowest and FF being the highest. So if you know how to mix RGB then you're all set. bright red is FF0000. bright green is 00FF00. pure blue is 0000FF. black is 000000. white is FFFFFF. medium grey is like 888888. bright magenta is FF00FF. etc

111155.question: the original Super Mario underground theme is literally only a 12 second loop. How did they get away with this?
111155.answer: they chopped off some empty spaces in the first 4 bars, which shortens it from what it would have been if the bars had been complete (like in the later versions with drums). and also, the levels are not very long. also, perhaps going so crazy on the last line probably makes up for the shortness. it'd probably take way more than 12 seconds for a person just to process all those crazy note choices in that final line. But i think the more important issue here is not so much 'how' but 'why' was it necessary, and the answer just comes down to technical limitations. surely they must have been working on an unimaginably tight computational budget, compared to today's standards. make every byte count. and when you truly have firm limitations, that's when the miracles just happen. because they have to

111167.question: For "more than a dream" in the bit where it goes "dum dum dum woah dreams make sense ", am I right in saying you go to a 2-5-1 in F#major, but the second time round you go to Emin7 after the lyric "and the best days you'll beleive again"? . Then going to an A major ish chord which would indicate that we're in Dmajor right? But you go back to F anyway. I noticed that you also teased a movement to D earlier in the song. In the bit "I can't beleive what I'm seeing , it's more than a dream , it's more than anyone ever dreamed in history" where you go from gmaj7 to Amaj , somewhat suggesting a 4-5 movement relative to D, and resolving to D at that point would make sense to the ear yet somehow you manage to return to F and still get it to sound natural. I'm intrigued as to how you managed wander everywhere harmonically and end up at the same place as if you were never gone. I also very much enjoy the Dbmaj7 to Ab maj7 vamp you managed to fit in, and if it isn't too much bother, what chords did u use to get from that vamp back to F major ?
111167.answer: yep right just about. it's like A7sus4. and yes, the key of the moment right there is definitely D more like A7sus4, and yes, the key of the moment there is definitely also D absolutely yes UNLESS you've been listening to the song since the beginning yes. this is common and normal. especially considering that keys a minor 3rd apart from each other tend to be like ghost cousins. very easy to slip back and forth between the two to find the right moves, the writer really never knows what it's gonna be. for best results, almost like a sneeze, you have to almost forget your trying. you have to be very open to where the song wants to go. trying to tell the song where you want it to go will make no one happy. It's also quite common and normal for a song to find its way back to the same key as it was before, when returning to the same part. but you have to be open to whatever the song wants to do. Sometimes the song will easily yank back to F (if it was in F before). Other times, it may want nothing to do with F. And, of course, you have to also be open to not just the chords but, as always, the sum total of what the melody, chords, words, and any other context, is doing. that's the only way to really find where things go at any given time on "anything" it's like Gmin7 possibly avoiding the D note. then Dmin to start the chorus as normal

111230.question: You said earlier that keys a minor third apart tend to be "ghost cousins" and while it could be argued that this is solely because that's the distance between a minor key such as D minor and its relative major , F, I was gonna ask do u think that movement between said keys can happen even if they are both major? As I mentioned before you did this is "more than a dream" where the fact that the bit in D was major was hinted at by having a Gmaj7 in there, giving an F# in the melody. You ve said that this is a very natural movement and it does sound as such, so have you used this same harmonic technique in any other songs of yours?
111230.answer: when i said that, i was specifically talking about when both keys are major (or both minor). if one is major and the other is the relative minor, i would consider those to be the same key. but indeed the reason that (for example) Fmaj and Dmaj slip so easily, is essentially the same reason that Dmin slips so well to Dmaj. (for the folks at home, you might know this as the "parallel major of the relative minor" of F). but the important thing is, this is not discovered by deliberately trying to slip a minor third. it's just simply by finding how you want the song to go, and go there. Zero times have i ever deliberately decided to do a minor 3rd slip on purpose. in fact, sometimes i am driven to avoid it and find some other amount to slip, just for something new i'm not sure which thing you mean, but whether you are talking about slipping to minor-third-away sister keys, or landing in a new key on its 4maj7 with 3 note of new key in melody, both seem to occur quite frequently in my writing. again, in zero cases is this premeditated. the technique is to dive where i want to dive, and then let the analysts analyze later, which of course has no effect on the song, unless i notice certain maneuvers that are just happening way too often and then i try to avoid them for a while and find something new instead

111234.question: how do you go about writing a second verse when the melody is already pretty clearly defined by the first verse? i'm totally fine with writing the melody and lyrics at the same time, and i'm even decent at writing lyrics for a melody that has no lyrics attached yet at all, but writing lyrics for a pre-existing melody WHILE keeping it cohesive with already existing lyrics is shockingly difficult
111234.answer: i have good news and bad news here. the bad news is, what you are trying to do, you cannot do. you are trying to 'write the song'. and you simply can't do that. this is extraordinarily bad news, unless you realize that the song actually wants to write itself. In the cases where you already have a first verse, and if the song wants to use that melody again, it actually comes extremely easy when the time is right. Actually, when it comes, it's likely that you may get a flood of 100 verses that all seem super good. but it never happens when you are in that frustrated mood of "i can't get this". it's a bizarre phenomenon, but just think of it this way: the song is going to come to you as soon as it feels it will be appreciated. and sometimes, when you're frustrated, you'd probably really appreciate some surprises, i bet

111379.question: there are different ways you add text to already shown subtitles: - the first one, you show the whole text at the start of a sentence. - the second one, you add words to the text and , if it's centered, it changes position on the screen - the third one, you add the whole text but it's masked and then you add words to that mask so, here's my question: how do you decide which method to choose?
111379.answer: the second method you mentioned, in my opinion, always feels terrible and i never do it (unless by mistake). and the third one you mentioned i didn't understand your description. but here's my basic theory for it. first, some terminology... "word pops" is when the words appear one at a time. "cumulative word pops" means each new word appears, with the previous words staying there. "replace word pops" is when the new word appears and the old word disappears, with only 1 word ever on screen at a time. "entire phrase pop" is when multiple words appear at the same time. Generally, in my opinion, when doing cumulative word pops, it's very uncomfortable for the staying words to move when the new word hits. this is why your second option doesn't work for me. However, often, i might want the final result to have a centered feel to it. in that case, i actually use left justify and use spaces to get the final result how i want. then i do the cumulative word pops to work toward that, so the words don't jump. "Replacing word pops" usually means the words are fairly big, maybe even full screen. Replacing-wordpops tends to be uncomfortable if it's a normal (fast) paced sentence. replacing wordpops is usually best for like a 3 word sentence where all 3 words are strong and emphasized. Otherwise, when deciding whether to do cumulative wordpops vs displaying the whole thing all at once, this is what i've noticed: alltogether works better when the sentence is an already-known quantity. a typical sentence. in other words, when i expect the viewer to already know the sentence. in other words, it's a sentence with no surprises. such as: "how are you doing?" or "i'll see you tomorrow" or "i never noticed that". It's basically a sentence that functions as one word. it's a package deal that everyone already knows. That's when it's usually best to make the whole sentence appear at the same time. But when the sentence is more unique, or has surprises in it, that's when you want cumulative word pops. Another method, for different situations, is "letter type" where it appears one letter at a time, steadily. This seems to be best when it seems to be some kind of pre-written, impersonal, formal message

111398.question: you said in an earlier question that apples and oranges are the same while I completely disagree. would you care to elaborate
111398.answer: there is currently an "apples and oranges" reference in common english, which has persisted for quite some time, and is still very active today, by which people always seem to mention "apples and oranges" whenever they are talking about any 2 objects which are "impossible to compare." it's "like apples and oranges", they say. It seems absurd to me, because apples and oranges are actually ideal for comparison. They are both fruit and have many similarities, and their differences are therefore quite obvious. They are just about the perfect thing to compare. So sometimes i am driven so mad by this constant sort of zombie-like widespread mindless obsession with "apples and oranges" being so "hard to compare" that sometimes i just blurt out that they are the same. I bet it's been a hundred years since anyone has ever actually checked, to see if they are

What I'm asking about is what you would consider the key to be at these examples coz in 9 8 7 the C chord is like a sus4 7 with hints of major but I think the G chord that is in "I'm scared " on the words "whelmed about something " seems to suggest a minor kinda sound. 111739.question: Ok so like, I was wondering what the point of life was, and I figured out that it was the dot on the i of life, which is in fact a point, but then I wanted to find the meaning of life, so I thought that the meaning of life must mean the mean of life, so I translated all the letters of life alphanumerically until L=12, I=9, F=6, E=5, then I found the mean of that dataset which is 8, and then I realized that if you combined the mean of life and the point of life, you would truly have the answer to life so that makes .8 and now the word life is missing its point which makes it llfe, but at least now we have the true answer to life, but then I remembered that the answer to life the universe and everything was 42, so I reasoned that to find the answer to just the universe and everything, you must subtract the answer to life from the answer to life the universe and everything, meaning that the answer to the universe and everything is 41.2, but then I wondered which part of that is the universe and which part of that is everything, and I realized that since everything contains the universe as well as infinite nothingness, and since the universe is not inf inite, then the value of the universe actually approaches 0, and thus every thing must be made out of 41.2 nothingnesses. If you've made it this far you might be wondering why life has a value when it to is not infinite, and the answer is that life contains some of the infinite nothingness, for example my life is full of infinite nothingness, which is why I'm happy to say that life definitely equals .8 wait am I thinking about this too much?

111791.question: in "got some money", what was the purpose of putting "memory" in the cuts between "aaaacv" and "frenca", "frenez" and "loveqa", and "lovesz" and "zzzzya"?
111791.answer: What i would have preferred to do, is to be able to actually create that entire alphabetical phrase list. which i was able to generate quite easily, but the problem we run into, when the list goes into the graphics, .... the list is so long that it actually makes the computer lag, or probably even crash, depending on how you do it. There's literally millions of lines in that text pattern, if it were carried out properly from a to z across all 6 characters. So even though it's just text, it actually is an absurdly unnecessary strain on the memory of the scene, pretty much any way you slice it. And the truth is, in that scene, with the small amount of time it's shown, you'd never see all the lines. and also, another reason you don't wanna include the whole list is that the scroll direction would become incoherently out of phase. like those car wheels on tv that seem to move slow or backwards or whatever. So it turns out, even just to create the proper looking downward scroll, you need to reduce the number of elements drastically. like pretty much skip 99% of the parts during the fast scroll. But this still does create a continuity problem, because if anyone sees the (maybe 1) frame where you can see it jump from A to L or whatever, .... i feel there's gonna need to be an explanation there. So my explanation is 'memory' as a place holder for the perhaps millions of lines we've skipped

111858.question: My list of song ideas, which are mostly just a few seconds of song each, is getting shockingly large. Like, it's well over a hundred, and I've only been collecting them for a year. I've written a few to completion, but it's always terrifying because I really really don't want it screw any of the songs up, because I kinda love all of them. I hope to start recording stuff soon, but that's a stupidly large rabbit hole that I've yet to really touch. So.... what should I do? Should I stop everything and focus on writing more for the songs I have? Should I just focus on trying to record stuff? I'm not really sure exactly what direction to go in, and this whole thing is feeling like a crisis at this point
111858.answer: that's understandable there are many good options here talk it out, and you should start to see which way you want to go. new idea generation is always cool, you CAN continue to spend some time on that, however, if the guilt is killing you then you can suspend new gen for a while if it makes you feel more comfortable. If zero-record is k√illing you, then you can suspend all writing for a while if it makes you feel comfortable. Now, assuming you will record, choosing which one and which order is nearly impossible, especially for someone who 'cares' as much as i assume you do. I'm sure that every one of them has immense desire mixed with immense fear. this is normal. On one end of the spectrum, you could try to just go through the list and choose which one you 'fear the least', but this might actually make you pick the most boring one. You could do a brute force random, which means leave it to the computer to make a choice (count them up and randomize). And this may be a good idea but it also might not give you the best results. i've discovered that a hybrid method tends to work best for me, and it goes like this: go through your entire list, and pick out any one that excites you. and add those to a pre-selection list. And by the way, amount of writing completion shouldn't matter here. all of them are available, including ones at .01% writing. if it excites you, add it to the pre-selection list. Then, as soon as you finish the pre-selection list, immediately count them up and let the computer decide from there. and that's the choice. then finish the writing on that one, knowing it is the next one to be produced. then once the writing is done, then go into production. this hybrid method (half my choice, half random selection) has worked well for me for a long time, but, to be fair, that was long after i already figured out how to record a song. The problem i had earlier with recording songs is that it was too overwhelming, and what i actually had to do was write insanely short songs on purpose, so i could learn the ropes on everything quicker. so you might have to do that, if you are feeling overwhelmed with longer items. or who knows, maybe you won't be overwhelmed. but if you talk it out for a while, i'm sure you can come up with a great system that suits your needs. there are probably a million different schemes you could do, and the method you come up with can be something you are really proud of

111931.question: i have a tune in triplet swing that i've composed on the computer. in the DAW i'm using triplets everywhere but just not playing the second one, to create a swing feel. i will be transcribing this tune to sheet music. i am experienced in a DAW but not with sheets, what are my options for communicating the swing on the page, and what do you recommend?
111931.answer: that will give you the extremely brash robot swing you used to hear in popular late 80s music. for a more reasonable swing sound, you'll probably want to find a 'swing' setting that puts the offbeat note somewhere between 55 and 59% of the way between the 2 downbeats on either side, instead of the 67% that you are currently using if the 8th notes are swung, write "swung 8ths" at the top. if the 16ths are swung, write "swung 16ths" at the top

111995.question: I know everyone has a different path of learning how to make music, but what do you think are the bare bones "music theory" (I don't like that phrase, I prefer to call it "music terminology") essentials for a beginner? I think knowing the names of the notes ( just knowing what notes you're playing) and knowing basic chord names are really the most important things. I was thinking maybe understanding key signatures, but I think you can probably write a chord patte rn/melody without fully understanding what key you're in or that this chord is the IV or that chord is the vii or whatever.. although that would probably be the next thing to learn after basic note names/chord names. Maybe understanding rhythmic counting? But I feel like if you have a good feel/timing you can probably get by without knowing all the rhythmic terminology and how all that stuff works. Learning to read notation, I think opens up more gig opportunities if you're a working, professional musician... Buts lots of musicians don't know how to read music, so I don't think that's essential for a beginner. I was thinking about getting into teaching, but I started so young that I have very little recollection of first learning. By the time I started piano lessons as a kid, I was already self taught to the point that I had developed enough feel to play simple stuff by ear. And lessons for me were more learning the terminology, scales, chord names, key signatures, reading notation, etc. But even with that, I was like 4 or 5 years old and I don't really remember much specifics from my very early lessons.
111995.answer: maybe it would be cool to find some kind of piano keyboard and start playing with it that would be useful for communicating with other musicians i'd personally like to ditch the roman numerals. they're just numbers, and i think the roman is much harder to read. i prefer arabic numberals instead (1, 2, 3, 4). also sometimes called "nashville numbers" yes, that is definitely good teaching might be very frustrating for you yes, teaching will be very frustrating for you. except for that one student who is already a self-learner, who you will love, who also won't even need your help

112058.question: building on the question someone else asked, how can you really differentiate, say, A# minor from Bb minor? even if we take their relative majors, they're still the same thing. also what did you mean by change by more than 6 degrees? could you give me an example of that? could you also give me an example of, say, a progression where there's a clear difference between A# minor and Bb minor?
112058.answer: they sound the same, but on paper they look different. on paper, the key of Bb minor will have a lot of flats in the key signature. the key of A# minor will have a lot of sharps in the key signature. and in A# minor, all the note heads will be written slightly lower on the page adding or taking a way more than 6 sharps or flats. more than 6 moves around the circle of fifths going from the key of Ab to E, on paper is like adding 8 sharps, but really it's gonna sound more like adding 4 flats on paper, everything is different. by sound, nothing is different. no need for examples. it's everything or nothing, depending on whether you are talking about the way it sounds or the way it looks

112186.question: Helpppp in a moment of inspiration I started writing a song that I'm really happy with, but then the inspiration passed and days later it's still where it started and I can't seem to figure out what to do with it now
112186.answer: this is normal, except for those rare cases where you can improvise an entire song. Most of the time you will find yourself in this situation, the 'second' half of the process, where you will be tasked to 'work' on the song, and find ways to coax or conjure up those inspirations again. i have some tricks. One trick is to just look to the original moment for answers. continue to tell the story of where you were and how you were when that first part came up. and another standard procedure is to run through the entirety of what you have, in order, in real time. another standard procedure is to ask categorical yes or no questions about it. "can it end here"? .... "does it want more of the same patterns?".... "does it want something completely different?" .... also another thing that happens is if you think about it for a while and then stop thinking about it, you might get the answer when you stop thinking about it. thinking scares music away sometimes

112236.question: how to stop getting writers block at the bridge of every song i make
112236.answer: not that there has to "be" a "bridge", but let's assume you are talking about that place around 1 or 2 minutes where the whole regular cycle of the song seems to have expressed itself sufficiently (perhaps twice already), and the question is "what now?". This is similar to the feeling that you have just invented a peanut (or something) and now you have to figure out why that's important, or what to do with it, or where to bring it. and truly this can be a big question. here are some questions you can ask, if you haven't already: can the whole thing just end right there? (you'll know if the answer is yes, or no). can it be sent back around again for a third time, in some different way? (you'll know if the answer is yes, or no). would it be cool to jump to something unlike anything that's ever existed before? (you'll know if the answer is yes, or no). if all else fails, try doing it wrong

112238.question: I saw a thing that said Unholy (by Sam Smith) uses the "phrygian dominant" scale. I'm confused about what that means because I thought the phrygian scale already has the b7 in there. Also, that song definitely uses the major third and not the minor. I guess that's what makes it "phrygian dominant"? (since the min7 chord doesn't have the tritone in there that a dom7 would). But you don't hear C mixo being called the "C dominant scale"? (Maybe you do, but I've never heard it called that). I know all this stuff is just terminology and isn't super important. I can play and improvise around the melody of the song regardless of the name of the scale that the notes are coming from (mostly root, b2, 3, 4, 5, b6, b7)... But I don't know, just out of curiosity, do you have any insight on this? The name "phrygian dominant" threw me for a loop.
112238.answer: certainly what they are saying is that it has a natural 3rd (which phrygian wouldn't). i personally avoid the word 'dominant' because nothing's actually dominating anything. misleading. indeed, phrygian nat3, is what i'd call that mode it's nice to have a handy way to talk about which set of notes you're using for the song 'phrygian natural 3' would be fine. but a lot of people maybe don't know the word 'phrygian', in which case you'll have to spell out the numbers like that. and if they don't speak numbers then you'll have to just show them which notes to use and then you're good

112259.question: what are your views on day/month/year date ordering? surely that or year/month/day make more sense, but then it always ends up being month/day/year (presumably because someone shortened that second one to month/day and bunged year onto the end later)
112259.answer: there are different reasons for different ways that way sorts properly. so this is probably the best way for data and file name systems. for example: 20230605220510. but for human reading, it puts the year first, which is not always what you want to focus on month-day seems like a good way to present month and day information. the problem is, of course, if you specify the year after, then the information becomes out of order. so in europe and many other places (possibly everywhere except usa) it goes day-month-year, so the information goes in a consistent order. of course it still won't sort perfectly, because the base 10 numbering system puts the smaller bits on the right. so for day-month-year to sort perfectly in a computer, we'd have to spell our numbers backwards

112347.question: so, i've spent a while trying to figure out the chords to the first verse of "i like to wear soft clothing", and i ended up with this for the first 8 bars after the intro: Bb6 Cm7 | Dm F7sus2sus4 | Bb6 C7sus4 | Dm F7sus2sus4 | Bbadd9 Cm7 | Dm F7sus2sus4 | Bb7 Cm7 | Dm F6 it seems to mostly repeat with minor variations. i did come across one kinda odd thing, though: in the 6th bar, on "me", the vocal is on a D, but there's something playing an Eb a minor 9th above it. i didn't really know what to make of that, so i just picked the Eb to put in the chord and left the D out of it a lot of this is probably spectacularly wrong (some of those notes feel REALLY quiet - hell, i may have started making them up at a certain point), so i'd love any feedback you may have. thanks!
112347.answer: there's no way those 1 chords are 6's. that should be Bbmaj7. and there's no way the 2 chord is C7sus4 the second time around. should be the same as the first time. this is just a repeating cycle. any variations are up to the players, but still, that second Cmin7 chord would certainly never be missed sure that's fine, although it's fairly likely that the guitar is doing like Ebmaj7 (with F in the bass, or the bass may be doing G to A there. i don't recall) i'd prefer not to listen to it at this moment because listening to the recordings can bring up some anxiety for me, so i'll only speak about it from memory, but i'd have to assume that the guitar/chord part is probably just repeating 2 voicings (Bbmaj7, Ebmaj7), and then the bass mostly probably will go 1, 2 to start (or sometimes maybe 1, 4), and then often 3, 4-5. or sometimes 5, 6-7. i'm also aware that i forgot to do it the way i wrote it. the way i meant it to be, for the bass, was more like 1, 4, 5, 6-7. OR sometimes maybe 1, 2, 5, 2-5. in actual reality, when i got on the bass, i just played the song instinctively and forgot about the specific chord choices i'd made when writing it before

112367.question: I wrote a song as a lead sheet and want to know how long it is. It's 112 measures long, in 4/4, and 119 BPM. How can I gauge how long it is, without having an opportunity to record it. With Math?
112367.answer: 4/4 means 4 beats per bar, and it's 112 bars, so 112 x 4 = 448 beats in the whole song. at 119 beats per minute, ... 448 divided by 119 means 3.76 minutes. about 3 minutes and 3 quarters of a minute. so that's 3 minutes and 45 seconds

112434.question: is transcribing/learning keyboard solos from songs i enjoy a good way to improve my improvisation skills? or is that bad, because it locks me into learning predetermined stuff, which is the opposite of improv

However, it does seem to perhaps give a sneak preview of some of the things that may be possible later when you actually learn to set yourself free like they have. something to look forward to it won't hurt you. but i think the magic of improv is going to come from somewhere else. somewhere no one else has been before

112479.question: I've been thinking about how much something's/someone's reputation affects people's perception... Like, are the songs in the "Real Book" great, timeless pieces of music and therefore were chosen to be in the book for that reason, or have the songs become standards BECAUSE they were put into the Real Book? If the Real Book was never published, would a whole new set of songs have become "the standards"? Or what if Shakespeare never published any work when he was alive, and nobody ever heard of him until someone in the 21st century just happened to digup some chest in some old crypt that had all of Shakespeare's writings... would 21st century critics still be like "OK, this guy is the greatest playwright and greatest English writer of all time... we must make high school and college students study his work"? Or if Jimi Hendrix wasn't on every magazine/internet list as the "Greatest Guitarist of All Time", would as manyguitarists still think of him as being so great? I remember my dad playing me Hendrix when I was a kid and saying something like "Hey, listen closely, this guy's the best." All our lives, I feel that we are explicitly told by schools, articles, magazines, parents, etc. "This artist is great because blah blah blah... that artist is a genius because blah blah blah..." You know those little memory-eraser things fromthe Men In Black movies? I wonder if the whole world had their memory erased, but all the music, art, literature, etc. still remained... would peoplestill gravitate towards what is today considered "great"? Sorry, I don't know what my question is exactly ... just ramblin on over here.
112479.answer: there are different types of songs in there. a large percentage of them were already standards for a long time before they were in the book. These are things like 1930s songs with lyrics, many of which were featured in theatrical musicals, and were very popular. There's also a totally different, fairly small category of music in that book, which are songs that were trendy amongst the players who compiled the book at that time. many of those ones are probably not-so-classic, and certainly are not standards. but, regardless, there are plenty of tunes in the book that just, for one reason or another, just usually aren't good, or they aren't good when played from the book. so these are the ones people don't like to play. they turn to the page and say "hmm, let's try this one" and then it's like "eich, no that one sucks" and they don't do it. but then there are some that just shine like the sun, even through the paper. so naturally those ones are the good ones. And very often, the ones that were big hits long before the book, are damn great in the book also, even without the lyrics. what tends to make something a 'standard' is if it endures popularity for many many years. Generally if you look at the songs played at weddings, or in the pubs, you will get a more updated idea of what today's "standards" are over all, in my opinion, the Real Book has had very little influence on what songs have endured popularity among listeners and players it would struggle against a 400-year language barrier. even though he was spicy fresh with the language, there is no longer a population of native speakers of the language base he was starting from. if he were born in the modern day, he'd surely do it damn great, starting from our language as we know it today and then pushing it forward from there if someone "assumes he is probably great", i don't count that. the exposure helps, but in a way it's a curse because some people probably feel pressured to like him so they never can give him a good genuine first-hand listen yeah, that's a real buzz-kill for music. music recommendation is extremely sensitive, and it can backfire easily yeah whatever, that's clickbait, don't worry about that. in time you'll figure out what really floats your actual boat no one's true feelings about anything would change. fake feelings however, would be what gets the re-set

112527.question: Is there a difference between add2 and add9? Would you play different notes for add2 vs add9, or would it depend more on context than how it's notated?
112527.answer: maybe but not really. add9 maybe implies that the 9 should be in the higher octave, but it's also fine to stuff the 9 into the same octave as the rest. the reason a person would choose to write "add2" on paper (and i do), is to avoid tricking the reader into thinking they should play the 9 way up high. and in that case, if i ever wrote 'add9', that means i'm probably saying i want the 9 to be high, because otherwise i would have written add2. however, for "maj9" for me it is usually assumed that the 9 is not high. just because, in the professional world 'maj9' has come to mean 'must include the 7 and 2 and 3 and optionally 5' if you can prove that the transcriptionist commonly uses both symbols, then indeed you can assume that the octave matters, because they would have used the other one if they meant the other one. but if they seem to always use the same one, then i'd say there's no way of knowing which octave they'd prefer for you to put that note

112542.question: What do you want your songs to convey to people? Actually I cannot point out what makes a song tick with me. Like with the Beatles' 'Yesterday', I like it but I don't understand why. I mean objectively it's a song about longing for a happier past, which is ... kind of ... lowly(Don't take this the wrong way, I feel there is some magic in the song but I can't explain it)? Like the right thing to do may be to move on right? So isn't it kind of... giving a message that it is ok to hang onto the past? But there are also songs about moving on like 'Let it go' from Frozen, which is sung in a situation when the character absolutely should not be moving on! But I still like the song. It feels like these songs don't capture the whole truth and I am finding it difficult to explain exactly what is the difference between them and absolutely lowly songs that only talk about sex, money, etc... that make me like them. If I were to make a song, I would want to give people the truth, or rather the peace or fulfillment that they want, but I also find that whatever I put into that song will be inadequate in doing so... How do you set standards for your songs in such situations, knowing all you can throw out there is incomplete and imperfect? I am asking with regards to your own songs. Obviously you have high standards, a particular way of making songs that don't talk about lowly things. Like for example your song "might quit", which is about leaving and doing your own unconventional thing in a way that makes more sense to you... I cannot explain exactly but I tried doing that for some time in my life and it didn't work out... I realized it was just a pipe dream. So ...I'm ranting a bit... I guess I'm asking what is that thing of unending beauty that you can rely on?
112542.answer: if i could explain it, then i probably wouldn't need songs to help me explain it if you ever figure out what is 'right' or 'good', then it would never cease. like, literally it would be just one note held down for the entire time. if that's the best note, then keep it on. if there were a 'best note', then why do we keep switching notes? so in that case, the only thing totally 'not-imperfect' would be total blankness without any disruption. but that's not what we like about music, it's not what we like about games, it's not what we like about 'taking a hike', it's not why we're alive. we are moving beings the entire world, but, also, any individual piece of that world is sufficient guidance. but i guess if you find yourself worrying about not being 'good' 'enough' 'all the time', then i suppose it's worth remembering that every picture ever painted has some lines that go in the wrong direction. otherwise there wouldn't even be anything in the picture. So, when you go to make a new song, get excited about how wrong some of it is going to be

112570.question: I often find new artists through looking through the Wikipedia pages for certain genres of music. For example, I found the band Television Personalities while looking at the page for "Anti-folk," and I ended up subsequently listening to their album "And Don't the Kids Just Love It," all based on the fact that the picture for Television Personalities at the top of the Wikipedia page was really cool. Basically, all this combined gave me the impression that this would be a cool band, based on their name, genre, pictures, etc. When I listened to the album, it was good, but it wasn't as good as I expected it to be, even though I couldn't possibly have had any expectations for their music. Would you say my expectations based on things that had nothing to do with the MUSIC of Television Personalities in turn made my experience of their album less enjoyable? Can that be applied to every artist? Is it best to just listen to a band's album cuz "fuck it?" as opposed to because "they looked cool," or "they had a cool album cover?"
112570.answer: no, it possibly made your experience better, because you were in a welcoming mood music discovery certainly works best when you are in that welcoming mood. because, at first, what else do you have? it's just the picture, the image, the title, .... you gotta start somewhere. so, indeed, these superficial attractors are a natural starting point. In fact, on some level i believe music actually needs something to latch onto, otherwise it doesn't even work so well. We've all had the experience of enjoying music in a video game. or maybe you'd go to a thrift store and see an obscure reggae record from 1973 that just looks magical. so you take it home and listen to it. Maybe it's good, maybe it's not, but being enchanted by how-and-where you found it, and the cover image, title, etc, certainly puts you in a welcoming mood, which will help you embrace all that may be good about it

112572.question: What inspires you to use strange time signatures in some of your songs, such as how more than a dream's verses are in 7/4?
112572.answer: sometimes it's just about how much time you want to pass. the first line is what it is, so we know that has to be like a 3/4, and then we try the whole thing in 3/4 and we notice "that doesn't feel like enough time passing in between the lines. i just want more time to pass" so we make the gap 4 beats long instad of 3. and that's how that happens. Same as determining how long each shot should be, for a scene of a movie. sometimes 3 seconds is too long. 1 second is too short. but maybe 2 seconds is just right

112578.question: Why do you think it is that we often feel so strongly that certain people "look" or "don't look" like their name? Like, oh you look like a Brian or oh she doesn't look like a Chloe. Do you think there are actually certain features associated with certain names? Is it just confirmation bias? Both? Neither?
112578.answer: on some level, there are some intrinsic qualities of visual appearance which may intrinsically match with some intrinsic qualities of some phoenetics. (i deeply apologize for using the word intrinsic 3 times, but upon further review i'm confidident that i needed it.) On top of that, there may also be some association happening with other people who have had that name. However, i should add, how people seem to 'look' is almost always heavily influenced by how they act, and how they carry themselves, and their personality in general. And personalities, also, may seem to intrinsically match with certain phoenetics. and this likeness may grow stronger over time, as people embrace (or, if needed, alter) what their name is

112584.question: i'm tryna make some songs here, or at least write songs to develop in the future, and i was just wondering, when there are multiple, varying in similarity, tunes/melodies/chord progressions available to work with that i'd like to incorporate at some point into my music, how does one figure out whether to attempt to cram them in the same song or save them for another song, all while keeping in mind if i don't use that cramming technique i would have to come up with a likely less musically satisfying melody to fill the gap and complete the song, while also keeping in mind that if i do cram, the song MAY possibly sound better given the incorporation of multiple flagship tunes, but then might not make as much sense or sound AS natural given that they tend to be completely, or at least enough that it's noticeable, different. how do i figure out the correct balance?
112584.answer: generally, i'd say don't obligatorily include things into a song just because you have them on hand. in my opinion, working on a song is like being a doctor, and the song is the patient. examine the patient, listen to the patient, and find what that patient needs. don't just go into your doctors closet and get the bone saw just because you have a bone saw

112587.question: If they say "short" for both height and length why is it that a great height is "tall" and a great length is "long"?
112587.answer: "long" and "tall" are different concepts, so i'm not surprised that we have 2 words. i find it more interesting to wonder why we have only 1 word for small height and small length. Some other languages, however, have different words for small height and small length, but only 1 word for long and tall. i guess the takeaway here is, there's never gonna be infinite words, so some sharing will have to happen. and, like cloud shapes, each language will have a different configuration of such sharing
