112590.question: What do I do if I wrote a super awesome song outside of my vocal range? I can sing the problematic part an octave down, but it just doesn't feel right. I can also move everything down until it fits in my vocal range, but the lowest parts feel way too low then. Do I just hope and pray that I can eventually sing it as it is?
112590.answer: among the things i would recommend, i do not prefer the 'octave-down' solution. However, i have 5 other semi-strategies (at least one of which you've mentioned) which all have their pros and cons. You can search for a compromise for the song's key, which sounds like it will be a tight squeeze because it sounds like the range of your song is wide. but, indeed, do what you can to find a compromise key. the next thing is just to keep practicing and eventually you will be able to sing a wider range. another option in the modern day, is to use computer assistance to produce the vocals outside of your range. the problem with that is, the results might not feel as genuine as you'd be able to get with your true voice, and also, if you ever are trapped in a cave with only an acoustic guitar, you wouldn't be able to perform the song, and also, in general there's a chance that it may hinder your growth as a singer because it might decrease your motivation to learn to actually sing it. Another option is to find a way to get someone else to sing it. the challenge with that, however, is that they just might not know how to sing your song as genuinely as you could, and of course maybe you don't even know how to find someone and/or incentivize them to do the job. Another option, of course, is to do a bit of re-writing to find a way that the song could comfortably land in a different key for that part. this may require some out-of-the-box thinking, but it can be done

112619.question: explain the theory of everything
112619.answer: that can be any length, so the theory would look different at each length. there is no upper limit on the length of the theory. so indeed the only non-arbitrary choice for a fixed value for the length of the theory would be zero. this unfortunately seems like it's leaving out a lot of possibilities. the second most non-arbitrary choice for the length of the theory would be 'infinitely' long. which actually shares the same problem as a zero-sized theory, in that it lacks any specific discernable detail. so indeed, anything will eventually lead every possible other thing, in due time, in a natural order that may or may not surprise even itself. enjoy

112675.question: Could you describe what a 13/8 time signature is?
112675.answer: sure. that means there's 13 eighth-notes per a bar. where in a normal time signature there would likely be just 8 eighth-notes. Indeed if we're counting we also notice there would be 6 and a half 'quarter-notes' per bar of 13/8, whereas in a normal time signature there'd typically be just 4. also it should be noted that depending where you live, a "bar" might be called a "measure", and an "eighth-note" might be called a "quaver", and a "quarter-note" might be called a "crotchet". and a time-signature indeed might be called a "meter"

112689.question: about six months ago i wrote my first 'good' song. it was the first one i felt comfortable showing to people, and it was the first one that my friends actually really liked and would ask me to play on occasion. i even had friends of friends tell me they liked the song. i thought that that would be the big victory i needed, and that from now on all i would be doing is making great songs, but since then, i've haven't been able to do anything. i try to write something and twenty minutes later i have something that's 'just ok' and i throw it away. i cling on to stuff i think 'might be good' and then realize a week later that it actually sucks. i'm less able to make stuff than i was before i wrote that first song. i tried the technique of 'making bad songs' but then i feel pressure to have some creative breakthrough while making it bad and i just make nothing. what do i do please help

112718.question: What do you think of Harmonic Minor Keys? Do you have any tips on how one could use them in songs? Do you have a favorite one? :)
112718.answer: it's really just a result of what happens when you are in the key of C minor and you use a Gmaj (or G7) chord no, but i can explain why they have a word for it. it's because someone was noticing that a 'minor scale', in C minor, for example, seems to naturally want to contain these notes: C, D, Eb, F, G, Ab, Bb, C. But what happens, often enough, is you go to your big strong 5 chord and it's G7 which has the note B natural in it. and the melody may hit that B natural too. so the person was looking for a way to explain this so they said 'what the heck, just call it a new scale and say the B is always in it.' But the truth is, the B only really will be there when you hit that G7 chord (or Bdiminished or whatever). When that type of chord isn't there, you could easily have all your Bb's as normal.

But if i were just playing/accompanying the vocal on one instrument, the C# note probably wouldn't happen. that's probably just happening in the twinkly bells. i assume you are not asking about the "gone" chord because that's at 1:53, and that's a whole different deal

112817.question: Cab you explain the Pythagorean theorem For me
112817.answer: sure. imagine a square, 1 inch wide and 1 inch tall. area is 1 (because 1x1=1).But how long is it diagonally? (wtf) longer than 1.... shorter than 2........ not 1 and a half........ what the heck is that number? got to be a super normal number, but it doesn't even seem to be in the same world as the 1. Anyway, try this: cut it along the diagonal to make 2 triangles. now take a second square and cut that one the same way. so now you have 4 triangle pieces. now rearrange those 4 triangles to make 1 big square. now you see, ... the height and length of the new big square is that ? mystery value from before. the area of the new big square is, of course 2. because you built this out of 2 original triangles which each had area 1. So what's the height/width of the 2 area square? in other words, what's the square root of 2? anyway, it's something point weirdsomething, but now you know a fun fact about the original 1x1 square, and what the heck that weird diagonal length was. indeed, it's the square root of 2. that should get you started

112828.question: okay i know that 4/4 means 4 quarter-notes in a bar, and that 7/8 means 7 eighth-notes in a bar, but what's a bar? and what's a quarter note and a whole note? does it relate to the tempo?
112828.answer: a segment of time in the music, like those big sidewalk squares are a segmnt of the sidewalk in most cases, a quarter note is 1 'beat' worth of time. a beat is typically the length of time that would recieve one foot tap, if you are foot tapping. in the normal time-signature (4/4) a quarter note is one beat. the 4/4 time signature is so normal that the quarter note (and thus all the notes) have been named in relation to a bar of 4/4. a quarter note is a quarter of the length of a bar in 4/4. and a whole note is the length of 4 quarter notes. in different time signatures, with different bar lengths, these names don't actually relate to the bar. the names are kept as if they are relating to a 4/4 bar, just because that's their name. at that point it's just a name yes. the tempo is measured in 'beats per minute'. so indeed if you increase he tempo, it means the quarter notes will go faster, the whole bar will go faster. the whole song will go faster. tempo markings often show a little note to actually indicate what one 'beat' note is. ♩=100 means there are 100 quarter notes per minute. ♪=100 means there are 100 eighth notes per minute

112830.question: in "money", when you say "i said it 3 or 4 songs ago", are you actually referencing a previous song or is it a meaningless lyric?
112830.answer: it's evoking multiple meanings. "hello, it's a tuesday show, cuz wednesday seems so long ago. i said it 3 or 4 songs ago. IT'S TIME FOR THE SHOW". Whether i'm referring to saying 'hello', or mentioning the 'tuesday show' or mentioning 'tuesday' then 'wednesday' in succession like that in a song, or simply declaring "it's time for the show", all of those are things i've either said before, or put in a song before. So that's 5 things at once that it means, and the 3-or-4-songs-ago is just an estimation, because all those things happened varying degrees of time ago. In the cases of things being put into songs, it's usually more than 4 songs ago, giving a whimsical over-casual sense to the estimate, but then the incidents where i've just said them (such as talked about them here on this page, or in notes, or otherwise in life) expressed things such as the desire to have a regularly occuring show, my preference for Tuesday for such an event, in those cases, the "3 or 4 songs ago" is just a way of mentioning time. indeed, when we say "3 or 4 days ago", we say "days" because days are something that happen so often and so regularly that they can be used to measure time. so it can also be seen that i'm sort of wistfully refering to 'songs' as something so regular and frequent that they ought to be used to measure time, even if just in casual estimation. most of all, all these meanings likely converge on "it's time for the show", which is indeed something that came out in an improv, in a similarly decisive and succinct way. these are the various meanings of that line, in context of the lines surrounding it

112856.question: there seems to be two opposing advices when it comes to creation and the "big idea". some suggest putting it on hold until you feel confident enough in your skill to tackle it without "wasting" the idea. But another seems to imply that other big ideas will keep coming so just focusing on it now is good. I feel like the first advice can end up making someone to never work on that one thing they really wanted to put out there for fear of never being ready. Since they could always improve more before tackling it. Maybe its just a matter of feeling ready? and maybe some people are adventurous enough to feel ready asap? maybe its not about being adventurous idk, im just kind of brainstorming and maybe projecting my own personal feelings towards this situation. Do you feel like writing a lot of songs makes you feel ready to tackle "big ideas" in other mediums/formats like storytelling? or do you feel its a different scenario enough to feel like you need to work yourself up to the more ambitious or attached-to ideas. One thing seems for sure though, if there is only one idea im passionate about, it feels obvious to tackle that one, but if more come it makes sense to hold off on the one i may be more-attached to or more ambitious about. I guess my "bad" feeligns towards the advice of holding until one feels ready is the assumption that it forces one to focus on things one is not passionate about. and it may come from a completely subjective situation of being REALLY passionate about one thing right now and the idea of forcing myself to focus on something else feeling like a dam would be placed in this current world building flow.
112856.answer: you can go ahead and work on the big favorite. but if you're too scared, then maybe you can't. now, you may ask, "is that ok?" and it reminds me of when they ask, in restaurants, "is Pepsi ok?" and the answer of course is no. pepsi is not ok. nothing is ok

112945.question: any reason that, when doing on screen lyrics, you break them up by word instead of syllables?
112945.answer: sure. the best reason for me to choose to show the whole word instantly instead of one syllable at a time would be: if i think the single-syllable way would look like crap. Generally i've experimented with a wide range of methods and timings for expressing lyrics on screen, and i'm usually going for what is most potent. timing is essential, so indeed i've tried the single-syllable way, but it almost always looks terrible and actually less potent, probably because we're so used to reading the words the way they are. by a similar token, sometimes in fact single-words is too awkward also, so i sometimes opt for entire phrases. i'm often pretty exhaustive in the amount of ways i try it, in search of the most effective

112948.question: bill on 7.29.20 9:24 am you got a question saying " Have you ever got brilliant idea(s) while taking a shower but forgot as soon as you leave the bathroom? It sucks when that happens " and you said you developed some near military grade memory tricks for makign sure that doesent happen please bill what are the tricks
112948.answer: here are some memory tricks. pretend you are explaining the idea to someone else, and start explaining it in as many technical ways as you can. Pretend you have to explain it to them so that they can reproduce the idea exactly, but, you are not allowed to actually demonstrate it. For example, if it's a sentence, say "the first word is ___, the second word is ____," etc... Count the words. remind yourself how many words there are. Say all the odd numbered words. Say all the even numbered words. Think of the first letter of each word, and put all those letters together. try to come up with an alternate sentence using the same starting letters. Try to access the idea in as many different ways as you can. If it is a musical idea, start thinking of the notation of it, imagine you are explaining the musical notation to someone else without singing it. List the notes in order. Count the notes. List the rhythmic values in order. If you don't know musical notation in this way, hopefully you have some other conceptual notation system you use to think about notes and time. What tempo is it? what song has a similar tempo? how many notes are in the first beat? how many notes are in the second beat? etc etc etc. Keep trying to access the idea on as many mental avenues as you can, and this will increase the likelyhood that you will be able to retrieve it. However, ...... if you've really just had the idea of a lifetime, and your life depends on it, then you can get out of the shower immediately and go write it down. it's a good feeling to know you have that level of professionalism

113006.question: there is something like a paradox called the ship of theseus. basically there's this ship and a guy called theseus used it to go some places. eventually the ship started breaking so they had to replace some parts and eventually they replaced every part. now the question is: is the ship still the same? if not, then when did it stop being the same as the old one? if it's the first piece switch that makes it no longer the same, then anytime you fix physical, it's not the "same" anymore. this keeps me up sometimes. please help

113061.question: hello, good evening, i hope you're doing well. music question: i'd like to make music, but for a myriad reasons never do, even when i have the time and will. one of the reasons is, of course, knowing that it'll never be as good as i want it to be. the only time i can feel at ease and just let things out is late at night when i'm improvising on whatever instrument, but that never results in a fully completed piece and any kernels that show promise never get planted and nourished, they're lost to the moment. which is fine, but ultimately i want to share the fruits of these moments with others. i've tried making them intentionally bad (usually when my friends ask me to make something for them), and that is definitely fun, but that method hasn't worked for my personal projects. wat do?
113061.answer: get yourself a pet list. (the list being your pet, not a list of pets). You say you generate a lot of starting points from improvs, and then they are "lost to the moment" because you're not in the mood to go into the office and do a full day's work immediately right on the spot. that's fine, and there's no need to do that. it's 2 different job positions. idea generator, and songworker. All you need to do, to complete your duties as an idea generator, is memo-record them and drop them into a list. Then, sometime later, on your other job as songworker, select items from the list and work on them. part of the problem could be that you were expecting yourself to do both jobs at the same time, which might not be reasonable. it's 2 different ways of thinking

113074.question: Isn't it a little strange that we have so many words for different quadrilaterals, but not for different triangles? We got square, rhombus, rectangle.... "equilateral triangle" is a mouthful. I wonder if there are any languages that have a special word for that, or other types of triangle, like how the Inuit have tens of words for snow. I'm still pretty stuck on rhombuses... rhombi? Rhombodes....? wiggly squares
113074.answer: i can't find any languages that have a single word for equilateral triangle. however, most languages do have it for square. I think the reason boils down to the fact that in our 3-dimensional world, the dimensions are at 90° to each other. which is what makes the 'square' and 'cube' so essential in our languages

113124.question: important Q (can't seem to find the answer anywhere; lots of disagreement): what are sharps and flats called collectively? "accidentals?"
113124.answer: that indeed is what they are called, when they are not in a key signature. so when you have to put them next to the notes as they occur, those are called 'accidentals'. Almost as if you....... 'accidentally' want a note that's not in the key signature, even though you surely did it on purpose. When it's in the key signature, set up at the beginning of the song, i don't think they are called accidentals. they are just called sharps and flats. With key signatures, sometimes i personally refer to adding or subtracting sharps or flats as 'degrees' to a key signature (in order of the circle of fifths), but that is probably not a widely accepted term for that, especially because it collides with other musical uses of the word degree

113137.question: Why do you think that books are kind of put on a higher "intellectual pedestal" than tv/movies? I feel like there's a positive connotation regarding someone who reads a lot of books (well-read, learned, smart, etc.) whereas someone who watches a lot of tv/movies might be seen in a more negative light (tv/movies rot your brain, the person is lazy, etc.). I can imagine parents being mad at their kid for sitting around and watching tv or movies (or internet videos) all the time... but if the kid was reading books all the time, the parents would probably brag to all their other parent friends "Oh, Little Timmy is such a smart boy! He loves to read!" I think, at the core, books or movies or television or even video games... it's all just different forms/mediums of storytelling? I don't understand why one medium is considered intellectually superior to others?
113137.answer: they are older. so they are a step or two higher up the formality chain. if you live long enough, you can indeed watch many of today's media formats get pedestalized just the same way, in comparison to whatever comes after ya, that notion rapidly becomes archaic if anyone still actually thinks that (and i personally just assume no one does), the amount of levels on which that's archaic is mindboggling. among other things, it fails to account for the fact that 99% of reading is not done on paper books. younger generations in fact, in personal communications, tend to heavily favor the text message over the voice call. so who's reading now whatever's been established longer will be more firmly accepted at any given time. i imagine when books were first invented, they probably were often viewed as a corrupting and harmful influence on society

113238.question: why is the series of chords "4 5 1 6m" so absurdly powerful? (subbing the 4 for 2m also has a pretty darn similar effect) i've come up so many melodies that use those chords, and i love every one of them. i don't think i could make a bad melody with those chords if i tried. i'm aware that a million songs have used there exact series of chords, but somehow it never gets old. like, the bridge section in "do the thing" uses these chords and it's so, so fuckin awesome there. thoughts on why these chords always just.... work?
113238.answer: i don't have any exact reason why that sequence might be good, but what i have done is extensively categorized and analyzed almost every common looping chord sequence. the ones that stood out to me as being the most reliably powerful, for me, were different from the one you selected. it probably varies from person to person. it's also worth noting that your sequence is a displaced 1,6-,4,5 or 1,6-,2-,5 which are traditionally known as extremely common. another thing worth noting is, categorically how does it make you feel when you start these things with 4 (or 2min). in my list of sequences, most of the ones i found to be most consistently the strongest also start with 4. For me, it probably tends to be "4, 1, 5, 5" or perhaps "4, 1, 5, 6-" that seem the most reliably strong. On the other hand, if we're talking about purely popularity, then it's hard to beat the infamous "6-, 4, 1, 5" which is almost certainly the winner in popularity, among chord loops, over the past few decades

113253.question: what's your compositional process?
113253.answer: it's a combination of 3 main processes. start, select, and work. the key to these 3 things is treating them all like separate job positions. the "start" department dreams up brand new ideas, and it really doesn't matter how small the fragment is. it can come from almost anywhere. the "select" department chooses which one to produce next. the "work" department already assumes that one certain item has been selected, and then sees it through to completion. the piece wouldn't exist without the "start" department, but the marjority of the composition takes place in the "work" department. the key to the "work" department is to consider the actual real-time effect that the piece would have on you, and then let that trigger what comes next, as if by lightning. and being struck by lightning is of course completely impossible, or extremely easy, depending on whether or not it happens

113255.question: What are chord progressions? Why does there seem to be so much emphasis on knowing the chord progression of a song to be able to play it?
113255.answer: an over-complicated name for just a bunch of chords the word 'progression' here is distracting and doesn't really make sense. it usually tricks people into thinking that all chords are somehow 'progressing', and that's just not true. it's like saying the rooms in a house are a "room progression" ....... really we just mean ... "the rooms". So, do you have to know what rooms are in a house, in order to build the house? well, yes, only if the house has rooms. if it's a no-room house, then you don't have to know the rooms. or maybe the rooms are already built and you just have to build the rest of the house. but, for a roomed house then you'll need the rooms, for sure

113277.question: How to do the impossible task of convincing people to change a deeply entrenched habit that unnecessarily(changing said habit does not harm the person who changed) negatively affects others, when there are no visible, legal, physical, or social repercussions to such people in continuing to remain as they are? How can I do this successfully while still remaining doing my office job(as leaving job just to convince people may not pay at all,i.e., it may pay but it is extremely risky)? Especially if I feel like the only way I can successfully convince someone is if I have a lot of time to sit around convincing every passerby(job takes up lot of time, with the little time I have left for convincing people, my efforts seem to be bearing no fruit)?
113277.answer: creating deliberate change happens from the inside out. the first person you truly have access to, from the inside, is yourself. your access to everyone else (from the inside) is unfortunately limited at this time. so therefore, it's been quite common that the most powerful results are found (for oneself, and, also, the world in general) when people look within and make changes there first. in other words, you started off by wondering how to change other people. but why aren't they changing themselves? perhaps, they are too busy trying to change someone else actually ...........

Please enter the number you wish to call, area code first." then you type the number, and then you probably have to say your name, and then it calls the other person, and it says something like (i've never heard this part, so i'm paraphrasing) "some jerk named ______ is calling you and wants you to pay for it. will you accept charges?" and they can say yes or no. and then if they say yes, you'll hear "Your call is connected." and then you are talking to the person

113330.question: is there a particular project of yours that taught you a lot while making it or is that just a standard thing for every project
113330.answer: the one that really comes to mind is the parking lot video with all the cars ("Perfect"). this really solidified the phenomenon that if you do something 50 times, even if you are clueless the first 12 times, you start to find your way by about the 14th, and then you get super efficient by about the 25th. I watched this same exact phenomenon happen over and over and over again as i worked the assembly line in the modeling of 50 car models. from aligning the assembly line in the first place, to setting the initial shape and size, to wheels, to chassi, to roof to windows to plates to every little thing, done in the exact same order through all 50 models, and i watched the exact same cycle of cluelessness at first, finding the method somewhere between 10 and 20, and getting rock solid on it by the 30th. So reliable, makes me want to apply it to everything. And of course the other element of that car project, was the fact that i actually had to produce not 50 but 4000. And at such a high quantity, it requires me to invent/program a technique for doing it. If i only had to make 4 cars, i'd probably just make them all individually, and i won't really figure out what i'm doing. but if i have to make 4000, then i realize i can make 50 models to give enough variation, then i automatically learn a hell of a lot when tasked with propagating 50 to 4000, and also in making the 50. I vaguelly knew about all these phenomena before, but after doing that project it really made me realize the wide range of benefits that comes with unapologetically doing 4000 of something

113335.question: Is the number we're looking for in "9 8 7" 1? The number that makes the whole thing blue would be, in RGB, a 0 for red and green, and a full value for blue. This could be interpreted as FF or 255, or 1 as in 100% of the blue channel on. Also, in statistics and computer science, 0 usually means false and 1 is true, which would also make 1 the number that makes the whole thing true. It also makes sense of the "2 and 1, what have you done?" as it would mean that we finished counting to that number, and the "1, 1, 2; 1, 1, 3; 1, 1, 1; 1, 1, meef" because at the end we find what we look for. I'm thinking of it as if it was guessing, "Is it 1, 1, 2? (No) Is it 1, 1, 3?..."
113335.answer: certainly a downward counting sequence starting with 9 seems to be headed toward 1..... also 0 of course the pivot point is more valuable to me, in a song. (the "whatever"). It's like when you sell a basket. the value of the basket is not based on the item you'll put in it today, tomorrow, or any other specific day. 113344.question: Sometimes I find myself imagining reality rather than observing it(and I'm liking what I'm imagining); I tell myself it is ok because I know it is imagination. So then I resolve to stop myself everytime I'm imagining, and that feels painful, and makes me stressed all the time. Does this happen to you too? What the hell even is happening and what is the solution? Should I stop myself from imagining everytime? If not, how do I never forget that what I'm imagining is not reality?
113344.answer: sure you're always imagining somewhat. that's how we function. the actual raw reality, even just from what your sensory sensors are perceiving, is a firehose of data, which is unmanageable. the only way we are able to live our lives is to interpret that data as a recognizable thing. "it's a cat", etc.... so there almost is no such thing as truly observing what actual reality is. you're supposed to interpret it, which requires some imagination

113351.question: Does what or how have to be in the result of a question, are there any other ways to form a figure of questioning? Also, whenwhy?
113351.answer: there are other ways you have 'what' (among an infinite amount of permutations), you have 'which' (among a smaller, finite number of choices), you have 'yes/no', you have 'when' (expecting a time), you have 'why', which expects some explanation for something, you have 'where' which expects a place, you have 'how' which expects a method for something, you have 'how much', which expects a quantity, and you have 'how many' which usually expects a whole number. those are all i can think of now

113669.question: I've tried your suggested experiment to keep all chord voicings within an octave (to get out of "stuck in root position block chords land"). But now I've encountered a problem: certain major 7ths are becoming flat 2's, which sometimes makes me cringe even in midrange. I googled a potential solution, "stride piano," which requires insanely frustrating left hand precision. If I don't wanna do this, will I just have to IMAGINE the bass note while playing non-root harmony in left hand, solo in right hand?
113669.answer: i don't see how stride piano has any relevance to this issue oh i see. you're trying to play melody things with your right hand, while also somehow accompanying yourself with your left hand. and i think, reading between the lines, you have no bass player. in that case, what you are doing requires 3 hands. if it were me, whenever i'm on a keyboard by myself, it's always bass in the left hand, and pretty much everything else with right hand, and, of course, my voice. If you are not allowed to use your voice, then i'd say just do bass notes with left hand and melody stuff with right. eventually it will become instinctive to start also throwing chords and harmonies in, with the right hand also. for example, if you play melody note E, and the chord is C, you might play E and C with the right hand. there's actually 1000 different ways to use the piano, and it's different depending on how many other players you have with you, and whether or not you are singing

113771.question: sometimes when i analyze a solo over a jazz standard i get too familiar with it and start to get convinced that the solo is just part of the song, it's the logical continuation of it. and then i have trouble trying to improvise over the piece myself, because 1. I feel compelled to just play the solo I analyzed, and 2. it's hard to improvise when i'm trying to AVOID playing the other thing. do you have any tips to break out of this? I've considered transposing the song to a new key
113771.answer: sure. however far out you thought you were supposed to go, just go 100 times further out. for example, the box you are stuck inside is sort of magnetic. in order to get out, you have to actually fling so far away that the magnet can't get you. for example, here's what you might do: as soon as the solo section starts, don't even play anything. as soon as the audience (or, you) starts to believe that you actually might not play anything, then you may begin playing, but play actually a different song, in a different key, at a different tempo. enjoy. The hidden truth here is that you will actually slip back nicely into what the backing song moves you to do, but, unfortunately this only works if you are truly not expecting it. so what i'd suggest is to delete these last 2 sentences and then read this all again yeah actually that might be enough

113889.question: what are the chords in the intro of "the road"? are they D, C+/G, Bbdim, D(#9)? or are they Dmaj7 Abmaj7 Bmaj7 (unknown)? or something else entirely? how did you come up with it (was it part of the "make it bad" technique or was it not that)?
113889.answer: that's close it's that, but i'd say you have to skip the Eb note in the Abmaj7, to give the melody room to do C D E. and the last chord.... i hear A in the melody, F in the bass, i also hear D, and it feels crunchy in a way that Dmaj/F would feel. Without opening it up, that's my best guess. Okay, i've opened it, and i was right. and it's also worth noting that actually none of the maj7's have their 5 notes in them. Also, plot twist now, there is more to the puzzle: in addition to the harpsicord (playing the chords) there is also a bell playing these single notes on each chord: D, A, C#, G#. so the Bmaj7 is in fact more like Bmaj9, the Ab chord is now extremely illegal (although the meat of the bell note can't really be heard, so it doesn't seem to disturb the harmony, surprisingly. only its twinkle seems to be audible), and the final G# just intermingles with what was already a crunch chord all i remember is that i had another intro written and it just wasn't working, and this is not it. so this is a last minute solution i came up with

114377.answer: it seems not entirely clear what 'extension' means. it doesn't seem to have any musical meaning. the chord is the chord. 'extension' implies it's different than it was sure. actually 'add4' tends to mean the 3 is also there. otherwise it's called 'sus4' if it's minor, you probably should either write "min", "minor", "-", "m", or put the numeral in lowercase. but i'm actually not sure if that many people can read roman numerals nowadays seems normal, except the way you notated the F is weird because it looks like it includes Eb and E notes at the same time. it's most likely a notation mistake, considering the rest of the sequence looks common and normal it doesn't sound like anything on the page. you'd have to play it somehow

114412.question: I need some help with some chord names... 114513.question: Do you sometimes plan the structure of a song in advance? I'm torn between free-form-writing as it comes and the clarity that comes with a fixed form. (And also it's much easier to work towards "let's do an AABA tune".)
114513.answer: it's mostly impossible to know exactly what the form will need until you start writing it, however, the song will offer you clues. sometimes the initial idea will very clearly be a 'chorus', and sometimes you get a clear picture of what it will need. other times, the first idea will be like the title at the beginning of the A of AABA. it's really all about taking the initial idea and 'diagnosing it', with the most important question simply being 'is this the beginning or not the beginning'

114525.question: What's the difference between "There it is" and "It is there"? In what situations is one or the other preferable?
114525.answer: first of all, the elephant in the room, "it is there" is particularly uncommon because in that case you'd use the contraction "it's there". so the difference between "there it is" and "it is there" would actually have multiple layers of difference. other than that, here's what i can offer: "there it is" seems to occur at the exact moment that the speaker finds the thing. where as, "it's there" is more likely to be an answer to a question, like a clarification about whether the thing is there or not there

I'm not 100% sold on the idea, but it's fun to think about past lives. I have this thought that consciouness, much like matter and energy, cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. 114564.question: opinions on the time signature 6/8
114564.answer: it's normal, but it's important to know that it actually behaves more like 2/4, with triplets, as if the triplets are written without the 3, and the non-triplets are written with a dot. it's also my opinion that 6/8 should be used in many more cases than it is. when people use 3/4 and the quarter note is extremely fast, almost like 1 beat per bar, it's my opinion that 6/8 would be better. and also in cases where 4/4 is used with triplets at a very slow tempo, it's also my opinion that 6/8 should be used. in both cases, it brings the bar length closer to a more normal time length of about 2 to 3 seconds

115263.question: oh, ohhhh. okay so knowing scales is perhaps important to know chord nomenclature? a major chord is the 1st, 3rd, and 5th note of the scale. a minor chord is the 1st, flattened 3rd, and 5th note. sus2 is 1, 2, 5. Csus4 is 1 4, 5? okay but what's the difference between a minor scale and a major scale? and the difference between playing in a minor and major key? and a what is a major chord in a minor scale? and can chords be shared by two scales? fuck. how do i learn chords and harmony without learning scales? i wouldn't mind learning scales but i want to play freely
115263.answer: maybe yep C major scale would go like this: C D E F G A B C. and the C minor scale, at least the first part, goes like this: C D Eb F G. and the rest of it may depend on what the chords are at any given time explaining this is like explaining the difference between a happy face and a sad face. it's not always possible to explain the difference, but you can just sense it. and of course some songs play tricks on you and kind of use both. other songs are very clear about it. jingle bells is major. "stayin alive" by the BeeGees is minor. generally, in a major key song, the "1" chord (sometimes called the "root" chord) would generally be major. and in a minor song, the "1" chord would generally be minor. now, how do you know what the root chord is? again, it's similar to knowing which side of someone's face is the top. how do you recognize this when a person is lying on their side? i have no idea, but you just know somehow well, if you are in the key of C minor, it's fairly likely that you may hear some Eb major chords somewhere in the song, or Ab major or Bb major. Actually, it's fairly likely you may even hear the G major chord somewhere in a C minor song. that gets back to what i was saying about that part of the minor scale which tends to flex based on what chords are there sure..... a C major chord would be likely to be found in the key of C, but also likely to be found in the key of G, or F, or A minor, or D minor, etc no need to worry. just keep listening, keep playing, and let yourself be curious about whatever you find yourself curious about at any given time. it's all there for you, and also, it's magic, which sometimes makes it impossible to explain, but it's also the whole reason you're into it in that case, my recommendation is to just never play scales in order. and also, as soon as you can, make friends with the 'chromatic' scale, which is just all the notes

115265.question: how would you analyse the function of the VI in a I VI IV progression? (example: toby fox's "fallen down")
115265.answer: first i'd translate it to arabic numerals (or even just pick a key and use letters) because roman numerals make my eyes bleed (that's just a personal issue i have). then, checking what the song sounds like, i'd consider it more specifically than what you wrote. i'd say it's Dbmaj7, /, Bb7, /, Gbmaj7, Gbminmaj7, Db, Ab. (actually the whole thing seems to be tuned somewhere in between the key of Db and D, so don't take those chord letters as absolutes necessarily. still only using them for relative purposes) as for your question, my analysis of the function of the Bb7 in this case is: it's musical. it reminds me of things i've heard in other music, and, this song is, in fact, music, so this doesn't surprise me. reading back over this it occurs to me that you might not think i'm serious, but i am in fact dead-on serious about all of this. music is precisely what's happening here, and that's no joke. i've dedicated my whole life to this stuff

115314.question: If Valentine's Day candy is the worst Halloween candy, Is Halloween candy the worst Easter candy? And is Easter candy the worst valentine's candy, like a form of holiday candy rock paper scissors?
115314.answer: my reason for suggesting valentine's day candy as the worst halloween candy is based on the likelyhood that any valentine's day candy you can find on october 31 is likely to be fairly old, because most valentine's candy is probably manufactured around the previous december (at the latest). It was tempting at first to suggest that christmas candy would be the oldest, but the fact is that most stores actually begin putting out the christmas candy on halloween day, and have already moved the halloween merchandise to the discount area. so it's actually quite likely that even an ordinary consumer would be able to find brand new christmas candy, on halloween day. by this logic, easter candy would actually be the best and freshest candy on valentine's day

115359.question: i've been working with the chromatic scale. my strategy is to let every note feel loved, and also to use the piano to lead the rhythm. it sounds very janky and awkward and dissonant, but there was a brief moment where i could hum each note before i played it at a not-very-fast place. i think i want to be able to do that faster: predict each note before i play it. but i wonder if my answer lies in intervals... i saw a few charts where they didn't specify the key of the song but the note of the scale like so: 1 5 5 2 1 1. how would that work for the chromstic scale? it wouldn't, right? when i was playing with the form of My Favorite Things (by ear, at first), i found that i could be a lot freer with the melody than i wanted. but i don't know what to do. actually i don't want to predict each note before i play it. i want to play the note that i predict. this is my main struggle currently. beyond technique and all.
115359.answer: almost any exercise you can think of is probably good, but also be sure to balance that out with a lot of fun and good times usually what you'd do is use flats or shartps to show how it deviates from a major scale. so for example, 1, #2, 2, b3, 3, 4, #4, 5, #5, 6, b7, 7, 1 and of course for any of those flat/sharps you can choose between which way you want to do it (#4 or b5) depending on which one you prefer at that time i think you are doing fine. the brain cannot do otherwise than learn. over time, it almost doesn't matter what the strategy is. the learning happens. except don't forget the most important ingredient in music: fun

115414.question: how do you record percussion? clicking around in a piano roll makes me want to pluck my eyes out, but i'm not good enough at keyboard to use that as a midi controller. i guess a drum machine could work. and i guess i could just stop being lazy and get gud at manually inputting the midi events. what would you recommend?
115414.answer: you need dynamics (loud/soft). the problem with inputting midi notes with a normal computer clicking device is they are all the same loudness. that is precisely what will make it sound like crap, in that case. so whatever your input device is, make sure it knows how hard you hit it. that's the whole secret to good drums and percussion

115469.question: I recently showed someone a non-musical project of mine, and they said "I can't wait to see what you do with that next," and now I can't work on it at all. It was like magic. 115559.question: what is the root of a chord, and how would i find it? i imagine it as the note that i'd sing if i were to hear it, but that doesn't seem quite right... and what is an inversion? if C is CEG, then would the inversion be C, and then the E and G of the lower octave? but wouldn't that be a chord of its own? can a chord have two different names? also, how do i harmonize? i can't play chords in my left and the melody in my right and... have it sound good. just gotta keep playing, i suppose.
115559.answer: probably more than half the time, the note you'd most want to sing might not actually be the root. if the chord is C major, the root of the chord is C. if the chord is C minor, the root of the chord is C switching the notes around so the highest or lowest notes are different, but otherwise keep the notes the same. so switch the octave of one or more of the notes you can invert it any way you want. put any of the notes in any octave. just be aware that if you have too many notes too low it will be harmonically useless and more like a horror sound effect, but that might be useful too in the right context sure. chord names are never 100% accurate anyway. the only way to describe a chord exactly is to list the exact pitches that were played -- in fact, even that's not accurate enough to represent the exact sound. the only way to exactly represent a sound is with an actual sound wave the next time someone sings the happy birthday song, try doing this: along with the final 2 melody notes in the song, you can sing above it. for example, if they are singing in the key of F, the last two notes are G F, so try singing Bb and A along with them. magic. To explore more possibilities and learn the mechanics, maybe the best way is to use a piano/keyboard and start messing around and see what you like

115616.question: Usually I feel really happy and fulfilled by myself, living my life exactly how I want to - the freedom, the choice, it's all great. I feel happy by myself and rarely feel lonely. But then sometimes I hear other people talk about such a situation and person and even though nothing has changed I feel sad as if I'm reminded that "oh I should feel sad about how my life is" despite the fact that on the day to day I do exactly what I want to and enjoy it. It's not that I dislike other people but I don't want to make friends to not be defined as "lonely", if and/or when I make friends I want it to be organic and not forced. I don't like how stigmatized spending time with yourself (not just by yourself) is and even though logically I know that it should not be frowned upon and if you're happy that's all that truly matters, a part of my brain can't shake the feeling ofbeing judged and, maybe subconsciously, slightly judging myself. Just wondering if you have any insight on this or if it resonates with you

115660.question: i'm currently alternating between working a full-time job and being in university, both entirely unrelated to music. i have a fair amount of free time which i try to spend as much as possible on music. some days i feel like this situation is pretty good, but other days i feel like i am travelling down the completely wrong path, because i'm basically wasting enormous amounts of time on non-music. and when i look at all these professional musicians most of them went to music school instead of not-music school, and they got jobs related to music of course. and i'm scared that if i continue what i'm doing then i'm going to get "locked out" of the music world because i won't be good enough, or i won't know anybody, or something. what do i do??

115667.question: Caveman here, I hold a microphone next to the speaker of an electric keyboard every time I want to record music. I get the feeling that there's a more efficient way to record but the all midi apps I've tried either were too confusing or they produced something that sounded completely different to what I was playing. Do you have any suggestions, or should I keep doing what I was doing?
115667.answer: what you're doing seems great. you actually skipped a concept in between midi and microphone, and that would be direct audio (recording the audio through a wire, but still recording the audio output and not the midi). in which case you'd get the exact sound of the keyboard, not just the 'midi notes'. but it turns out, if you do that, you might find it disappointing that you can't hear the air and sound of the room, and, most importantly, the tapping sounds of your hands on the keys. also besides all of that there's another advantage of the way you're doing it which is of course that you are doing it. the other ones are in fact not happening, so they are pretty useless anyway in that regard

115708.question: do you think feeling lost in life is related to decision fatigue? (where to go to school/work, who to hang out with, etc) is it fundamentally similar to being lost in a physical space like a really big park or new city? like whenever i get turned around irl i know i can backtrack or use landmarks to find my destination. but how can i do that for "life"? how do you even decide what the goal should be? i get overwhelmed and frustrated thinking about all the things i could be doing. there's no clear objective like finding my car somewhere in the parking lot if that makes sense. idk i know i should be doing something different but how do i decide what exactly that thing is?
115708.answer: often yes could be well in that case you weren't lost. being lost is when you actually have no idea where you are, in relation to where you've been, or in relation to where you're going just start talking about it, and you'll start to sort it out. you said "what should the goal be" ... well, next maybe you'd think to yourself... "what is a goal actually?" "should i have a 'goal'"? "do i want to have a 'goal'"? depending on the answers to those, that will lead you to the next questions. basically you're just trying to get it down to one question at a time. if there's too many compounded questions at the exact same time, you actually can't perceive them, so it's just a foggy feeling. so you have to start sorting the mess of compound questions into something you can answer first. and the first several questions will usually just be about trying to figure out which questions you want to be asking there's no limit to the amount of ways you can decide. but a lot of those ways may also involve waiting for just a moment

115787.question: bill do u know why does nature make sinewaves? or why any wave can be broken down (approximately) into sums of sines? I cant really find anywhere on the internet that explains WHY, just that it is. If i throw a stone into the water, does it ripple sinusoidally? Why though? why not like a triangle wave? what is it about nature that makes it want to be siney? Is it really that way or is the sine wave just a good way to represent stuff? I saw an argument that it is used because its derivative is also siney but im not sure if thats it. Does nature speak sine or do we make sense of it through sine? I don't really know what to ask online to try and understand what void there is in my understanding of it. I know that it represents the movement of a circle, but does it mean that nature is naturally circular? and thats why when translated into one dimension we see sines?
115787.answer: why wouldn't it i'm not sure. i actually hadn't heard about that. i've never looked into it, but i think i'd like to at some point my first thought is that transfers of energy into different vectors naturally happen gradually and not instantly. that's just my experience with acceleration, or just direction-change in general. however, that doesn't necessarily answer the question of why our universe is like this in the first place. although i've grown accustomed to it being that way and it seems normal. but i could also see it being normal the other way also. like how color changes in a photo are usually gradual, but you could also imagine a universe with only 2 colors and no gradients, and that would make its own kind of sense it's been said that nature speaks calculus. this may be tangentially related to your argument circles are natural, i'll give you that that seems solid, except i think you'd still have to call it 2 dimensions. but it's just perpendicular straight dimensions instead of the radial thing

115989.question: I like it that an answer somehow achieves it's own flavour and meaning when it comes from a certain person, their doesn't have to be anything special about that person, but it's something unique about that person that makes what they say seem so powerfully something (it's especially from people you seem to have a great understanding in) - it's something I noticed when you give really short answers to questions, or reallyseemingly simple ones, it's not only the text - there's also the fact thatyou're saying it ("it's funny because I get what you mean by that" I sometimes think). And I also realised just now that that could apply to everything, and there's so many inaccessible layers to people's art or what they say that I'll never get, but it somehow is still able to touch me so deeply -or the opposite of that case where people want to let you in to help you understand them better - and layers are neither opaque nor transparent, there's a spectrum of openness and closed ness and it's pretty darn crazy I have to say

116000.question: if persons A and B have the same birthday then clearly that's 1 coincidence. meanwhile if persons A and B have the same birthday, and persons C and D have a different same birthday, then that's 2 coincidences. but say persons A, B, and C have the same birthday. are there 2 coincidences in this situation, or 3?
116000.answer: it's not entirely clear to me i'm trying to figure out just what we normally mean when we say 'coincidence'. it seems like, for compounding coincidences, it seems like the results have to be revealed separately. if you select 3 random numbers at the same time, and they are all the same number, that seems like 1 coincidence. however, if you select the 3 numbers one at a time, and they all turn out the same, then that would feel like 2 coincidences, because effectively your were surprised twice

116001.question: Is this question a paragraph? Does it need 5 sentences to be a paragraph?
116001.answer: in my opinion, when standing on its own, it becomes a paragraph when it takes up multiple lines without using linebreaks (return/enter). however, i believe a 1-line paragraph could exist only when surrounded by other paragraphs, as long as some of those other paragraphs take up more than one line (without linebreaks). of course this all depends on the width of the page. i should also mention that if you make the page so narrow that there's only 1 word per line, that also doesn't count as a paragraph because it becomes a word list. but as long as at least one line is wide enough for 2 words, then it becomes a paragraph again

116518.question: Hi, Bill Fair warning this may be a long and somewhat abstract question, and I apologize if this kind of question has been asked and answered before. I've been a fan of yours for several years now and enjoy many of your songs. The lyrics especially have intrigued me and sometimes puzzled me throughout the years. I've noticed in the past when folks have asked you questions about the "deeper meaning" to the lyrics of your songs you coyly respond with answers that read something along the lines of "deeper than what?". I'll admit, I once asked you a question like this several years ago on this pageand indeed received a similar answer. At the time I felt quite miffed, butthen I soon saw that many folks were asking this kind of question, and I believe I was asking the wrong question. You see, over theyears I kept thinking about this question I asked and your answer from time to time, and i think it started to make me ponder about the relationship that music artists can have with their songs, their fans; and the interpretation that their fans have of their music. I've seensome artists, when asked the question "what's the meaning of song [X]?", have a specific message in their mind they want song [X] to display, or perhaps a certain story they want the song to tell. In contrast, I have seen other artists not explain any specific "deeper meaning" to the songs that they make, and indeed these artists say that a song means whatever the listener feels they mean. For example, your song "And The Day Goes On" (one of my favorites!): I like this song a lot, and to me, the "meaning" of the song is to persevere and press on when life gets stressful or tough. However, I understand that others may not interpret this song the same way that I do, and it really doesn't matter to me how others interpret the song - I like it for what it is for me. But this does get somewhat to the crux of my question, and it's a hard question for me to articulate because I've never tried to write songs before. I'm not looking forcontext about certain songs, but I am curious in general about the relationship artists may have with their published work. When you write songs, do they ever have a certain "meaning" to YOU? Do you write songs hoping that your audience will interpret them in their own way and enjoy the song for what it is, regardless of what the song may (or may not) mean to you? Or is the process completely different? I'm curious about your thoughts on this idea. Thank you and take care!
116518.answer: that's because "deeper" is a comparison word (the "er" on the end). like "bigger, smaller", ... etc, if you use the word, you have to say the other thing we're comparing it to. sometimes people just say, like "is this lamp darker?" .... so i have to say "than what" because i need that second object to compare to. it's very hard to compare something to nothing. or at least i don't know how to do it that's not how i react to the question -- almost every time, it's just the simple grammar conundrum, in the mechanics of the "er" suffix yes, and the final song recording represents my best attempt at conveying that. if you find me using actual music/audio/song/graphic etc, then you can be sure that words alone weren't enough. in fact, they're barely enough now, to answer this question. i almost need music just to answer the question. so i'd certainly need music to express the things that i've used music to express. in other words, it would be impossible for me to express what i've had to use music to express, without music. indeed sometimes people come along and say something like, "can you express what you were trying to express in that music, except without using any music in your answer?" and the answer of course is no or i wouldn't have needed the music the most profound meaning is certainly processed locally in the individual (within the mind of the person viewing/listening), so indeed it would be expected that everyone's peak meaningful experience might be slightly different. that's just the way it goes, in the 'feels' business

116670.question: In some style guides, while formatting conversations, they put the comma inside the quotation marks like: "How are you Bill," asked literally everyone. What are your thoughts on this, and would you prefer things to be more mathematically punctuated?
116670.answer: i'm aware of that style convention and i usually disobey it on purpose because i don't think it makes sense. putting the comma outside the quotation, in this case, i find more appropriate in a textual environment. it almost feels like the convention is actually attempting to simulate a handwritten reality in which the comma perhaps is placed directly under the endquote. but its function is clearly acting outside the quotes, which is why i usually place it outside, and i don't think that hinders the communication at all

116699.question: In chords, how do you start on the 4? Like a 4maj7 1maj7 progression. Doesn't starting on the 4 make it the 1? I feel like the logic my brain is trained to use is incompatible with music. If you started on the 4 then wouldn't the listener feel like that was the beginning, and they'd expect you to go up TO the four?
116699.answer: for example, Emaj7 Bmaj7, in the key of B no. just like you can draw a face with the nose drawn first. you can even draw the nose in the same place as you would normally draw the eyes, but then as long as you draw the eyes in the correct spot relative to the new nose, it will still look like a face and the nose will indeed be the nose again with the face example, say it's a face with dot eyes and a dot nose. let's say the nose is drawn first. in that moment, maybe you can't tell whether it's a nose or an eye. but then when the other 2 dots are put above the first dot, it becomes clear. in the case of 4maj7, 1maj7, once you hear both chords, it settles. even if you thought the 4 was the 1 for a fraction of a second when it started. also the melody helps

116701.question: An earlier question of lyrics being like silent road trips sparked something for me and I really want to know what you think about it. In most situations where I've sat with a friend in silence it's largely because we're comfortable in each other's presence. We don't need to say anything to fill the air because we are just together. Nothing else is needed in that moment. While tension can exist in silence, doesn't "what should we talk about during the trip?" also create tension? regardless of when that's asked? It reminds me of trying to force something in a creative project that isn't there. or maybe isn't suited for that project. or instance if lyrics can't be found after so much is developed why try to add it in? It existed fine without it. Does it really need the lyrics to feel whole? Or do you think the project is asking for something different and unexpected to feel more complete? Challenging you to find a new solution if you will. Sorry if that was long winded I just found your response to the problem very intriguing and wanted to hear your take on it.
116701.answer: i remember the question/answer being different than that. would have been the lyricless piece of music, that would be compared with the silent road trip in this case sure if i recall, the person said they had completed the production on a song with no lyrics, and then they ask how to go about putting lyrics in it. and my response was, generally, "it's too late". this may not always be true, because i guess it can be a neat challenge to add lyrics to a lyricless song after the fact, but generally this is not the way it goes for me. usually if there's words in a song, they gotta be written with the song, not after. i think you're asking a different question: you're wondering if that person's song might not even need lyrics at all. and for that i have no idea because i haven't heard the song, but it's also not what the person asked about. the person asked about how to write lyrics

116843.question: in "the ending" at around 2 minutes in, the "true" text starts rising and you can tell it fell towards the camera from how it looks when its rising but the angle at which it fell makes it look like it fell away from the camera. how?
116843.answer: no you can't. it fell away, although it would appear similar either way. there are optical illusions that demonstrate this, and usually the viewer's brain just chooses one way, and then it's hard to see the other way. in this case, however, there technically would be a small difference because the camera has perspective to it. it fell away from the camera it fell back, but even if it fell forward it would be perfectly easy to swap it at the moment it lands, or at the moment it starts rising. however this was not necessary because it indeed fell backwards, and this is evident based on the perspective. as you can see, the width of the top of the word decreases as it falls

116872.question: If all matter in the universe is just particles interacting according to the laws of physics, then there's no real difference between me and this table. We're just piles of stuff doing exactly what that stuff has to do. Everything I think and feel, even thinking about thinking, is just a bunch of stuff following a list of rules I have no control over. The only argument that free will isn't an illusion and that feelings matter, is that they feel like they do, which feels like circular logic to me. I think meaning logically has to come from an external source, but I don't believe in an external source. If the universe is a big rube goldberg machine, and we're cogs in it (albeit cogs with an element of randomness thanks to quantum mechanics), how do you derive meaning from it without just saying "I feel like stuff matters so it does"? Because then anything anyone feels is true. The statement "nothing matters" becomes just as true as the statement "everything matters". My brain hurts, my heart hurts, and I just want stuff to matter so badly. Your music is one of the few things that distracts me and makes me feel better, but you're so wise all the time that I want to hear your thoughts. Not like, telepathically, but you know, on here.
116872.answer: i'm not following your logic there i'm not following your logic there either i disagree with that yes that argument would feel a bit empty 'who' doesnt so then it's safe to say that [whether or not things matter] matters very much to you indeed, if i'm hearing you correctly in my opinion, if this all-mechanical mindless cause-and-effect 'deterministic' 'no-free-will' thing were true, then we wouldn't be here to perceive it. we wouldn't even be aware of anything. so in my opinion the fact that you are here, aware of your existence, means that there is significant 'wiggle room', 'free choice', 'multiple futures which you can choose between', etc. If this seems bonkers, that's because it is. that's why you're here. if it weren't you'd be somewhere else. your bonkers consciousness has no business in a deterministic system. deterministic systems are already complete and the process of time is not necessary because all the results were already known. If you're looking for evidence of such bonkeristics in science, then you should check out how many different places electrons claim they 'could' be at any given moment

116947.question: I really struggle and battle with learned helplessness. Life events from the past have made me believe that no matter what I do, no matter how hard I try to build something for myself, it will never result in anything substantial. The fear of failure at the starting gate keeps me from chasing what I really want. It kills me Bill. "Living" life where I've given up my pursuit, my passions, makes me feel so absolutely dead inside. I know the things I want are achievable. I CAN take steps towards them today. But the trauma of my past has a chokehold on me. It's a cocktail of shame and fear that I'm not deserving enough. It feels like my desires, no matter how humble, are an act of selfishness. And because I'm selfish and struggled in the past, I still feel like I'm sentenced to suffer for the rest of my life. Dude, how do I even begin to let go of this? To have faith that overcoming this is possible? How do you pursue life again when you've been paralyzed for so long?

117162.question: how many time did you rehearsed "You get what you give" with Scary Pockets? or was it all writen?
117162.answer: basically the way they were running the show at that time was to just get in the room and start working on it as quickly as possible. and then start recording as soon as possible, even before it's 'ready'. from beginning to end it was probably less than an hour, and nothing was discussed beforehand. jack was certainly in a 'quickness is king' phase at that time. as i recall, jack came at it right away with this "and-of-1" hits thing in the verse, then my first instinct was to do 4-on-the-rim (clicks on quarters) in the verse. I really wanted to do halftime for the choruses, but i was vetoed (i didn't really like the fast 2-and-4 thing in the chorus). but i think we ended up putting the halftime in the pre-chorus. the ending was my idea

117166.question: you've often made the point that it's not a good idea for a creator to make things that appeal to others and not themselves. how do you balance this take with e.g. the financial reality of artists? i was thinking about this with relation to art, and even a thousand years ago, a lot of paintings and music were made presumably for religious patronage or rich benefactors, and not necessarily at one's own creative whims. idk
117166.answer: not quite, i think the point i make is that that's probably not possible, and it may be unwise to try. i sometimes say it would be like 'painting with colors you can't see' you can surely make things that other people like, by making things that you like, and then other people who have similar tastes to you will like it too. but if you are going against your tastes, then you'll actually have no idea what you're doing. again, like painting with colors you can't see. or baking with ingredients you can't taste. For example, you may notice that some other people like "slime" and you don't like such slime, if you say "well now i'll just make slime, and those people will like it", well, the thing is, those people obviously are seeing something in slime that you can't see. so if you try to make slime for those people, you'll have no idea how to make it because you don't know what they like and don't like about it. I just thought of a better example: let's say you are surrounded by people speaking a foreign language. you don't understand a word of that language: it sounds like nonsense to you. but you want to please the people who do speak it, so you try to write stories in that language. so you write the stories in nonsense because, to you, that's what that language sounds like. i think you see where i'm going with this

117611.question: i've noticed many of my favorite musicians are multi-instrumentalists who started on drums or whose best instrument is drums, you included. my main instruments are voice, piano, and guitar in that order, but i would really like to have that drum-based foundation/way of thinking about music & songs. however, i don't have access to a proper drumset right now. do you think a practice pad/pillow would be good enough to learn these concepts? any advice on how to incorporate "drum thinking" into songwriting?
117611.answer: to learn drums, in music, there actually might be something more important than owning a drumset and it's this: playing in a band for a live audience, where you are the drummer and thus are largely responsible for directing and guiding the rhythmic cohesion of the whole group, and hence the whole room. this is the part of drumming that i think will strenghten you in the way that you are looking for it's not something you can think about it. it's like knowing French, natively, then you start writing songs. you're not thinking about incorporating 'french thinking' into the songs, you're just writing songs which will probably end up having french in them because you speak french

118056.question: Ok, so I'm in my first year of university, but oops, I kinda hate it. Not the "being here" part of it, just what I'm actually doing. Like, at this point my life may as well be homework, which is horrible, because I don't have time to do what I really wanna do, and yet I still manage to procrastinate away my homework (because I hate it), getting nothing of any type done. There's SO much I wanna do in terms of songs and videos and expressing a billion things to every human alive, but I just...... can't. 118174.question: so i wrote a question for you a while ago about if you suddenly had to use a walking stick, what it'd look like, or similar, but i just remembered today at 4 am that i asked this question. i looked at my pinned notes to find the exact question so i can find the answer easier, but its nowhere to be found. ive looked through the website so far at this point im almost certain it isnt real, but it still feel real. all of this happening reminded me of how when i was younger, i would often send messages to famous people, and always getting no reply. i always felt bad about it back then and i dismissed it because i was just a kid back then, though my strong frustration at something this small has proven thats still the case. i feel as though things like this are becoming more common, where peole tend to be much more isolated and reliant on creators nowadays. its this bizzare blend of "this is a real person" and "this is my ideal imagined friend i constructed based on this person's art", that ive seen so often on the internet. ?
118174.answer: the question was most likely from december 2, 2023, at 11:58 am, and it said "If you suddenly had to use a walking stick every day, what would it look like?". and the reason i probably didn't answer it is because it evoked the idea of sudden back or leg injury, which was above the level of mental trauma that i like to subject myself to on the questions page. the reason you couldn't find the question in your notes is probably just because you forgot to write it down

118496.question: do you think zodiac signs mean anything?
118496.answer: they would be a degraded version of the information. For example, if it's 12:28 AM, and someone asks what time is it by saying "which hour are we in", and so you say "12AM". the accuracy of the time reading would be degraded, compared to the more detailed "12:28 AM". So, similarly, simply saying "Taurus" would be a degraded version of "17 degrees Taurus"

118516.question: I notice you seem to prefer traditional grip as a drummer, how did that come about? In my experience, traditional grip seems to be largely prevalent only in marching and jazz drumming, with marching snare drum, of course, being the origin of the technique. (As it so happens, I learned traditional grip first because the first kind of drumming I ever learned was marching snare, but I rarely ever use it anymore, I prefer matched grip for almost all applications I've encountered as a rock drummer, but that's probably entirely because I play a lot of rim shots, and I find those very challenging to do with traditional grip.)
118516.answer: a basketball fell on my left middle finger in gym class, and for a few days i couldn't bend it. so i switched because you don't have to bend that finger as much. then my finger got better, but i didn't want to switch back as long as the snare is aligned right, i don't think there's any reason for the rim shot to be more or less difficult with either grip, except the main reason it will be better with one or the other is because it's what you're used to or just what you like better

118621.question: Okay, so I've been cooking this 8 bar cadence (or sumthing), but I cannot figure a good resolution. C / Cmaj7 / Edim / Bbmaj7 Eb / Bb / ?? ?? / C But I cannot decide how to bring this home. Would you preferer: A) Bb / F / G7 / C B) Bb / G / G7 / C C) Bb / G / Bdim / C D) Something else? Would this work better in another key?
118621.answer: 1. chord symbols on paper are not nearly enough to specify the music well enough to make any useful decision 2. even if we were working with sound, we're still in the situation of "writing chords" which, i find, tends to be a futile exercise 90% of the time -- the direction doesn't seem to take shape until some melodies, words, or other meaningful handles come into play 3. assuming you did give me all of that, with sound, words, and melodies, and then asked me what comes next, then you would be asking me to enter into a co-writing partnership with you. which i might be willing to do but i'd first like to discuss the nature of the partnership a little before jumping into the project

118624.question: What should I do with my left hand when playing piano? I usually just play chords with it but I never really see people doing the same so it must be wrong, any tips?
118624.answer: what is your right hand doing, what is your voice doing, and what are the hands instruments and voices of the rest of the people in the band doing there are many different roles a piano player may find themselves in. 1. you may be alone, singing a song and accompanying yourself with the piano. in that case, it's likely that your left hand will take the bass, and your right hand will take the chords, and your voice will take the melody. 2. you may be alone on the piano without singing. in this case you will probably be finding a way to generally cover bass, harmony, and melody, in various combinations of ways with whatever hands you can. 3. you may be in a small band with only bass and drums and piano. in that case, you will probably be responsible for melody and chords, in which case you will probably find your right hand doing a lot of melody (and some harmony) and your left hand lending some harmonic support where possible, and staying the heck out of the bass. 4. you may be in a band which includes a bass player and another melody player (or singer). in this case, again you'll want to stay the heck out of the bass, you won't need to be the main melody leader, and your main job will probably be just harmonic support. and in this situation, you'll probably want to be very careful about 2-handed playing, because most of what you need to do will probably be in a very one-handed range. if you insist on being very 2-handed here, you will probably be crowding the ensemble here 5. you may be in a band which includes a bass player, another melody player, AND also other harmonic players such as guitar. this case is similar to the above case, but even more delicate, and it's going to require some direct communication with the guitar player, to coordinate who does what. there's a lot of ways the 2 of you could ruin each other's lives, but as long as you are in communication then you can build exactly what you need, together all of the above situations are completely different roles for a piano player. this makes sense, because the piano actually contains the entire range of musical notes. so depending on who else is in the ensemble, you could be doing as much as everything or as little as nothing
