118686.question: is it normal to want to argue with people sometimes but not in an actual argumentitive way. like, just getting all of your thoughts out all at once without having to engage in a real conversation i feel like real conversations can distract from what i actually want to say sometimes. it's easy to misspeak or misinterpret the other person when speaking face to face, because you don't have as much time to process the information and come to a reasonable conclusion. maybe that's why i like text-based arguments better. you can get everything you want to say out, then edit it when needed to make the actual words of your argument match up better to your true feelings about it. but on the other hand, i feel like maybe the opposite of that is true in a way. maybe when speaking face to face, you're forced to be more honest. you don't have time to go back and deeply consider every one of the other person's claims. you have to make a snap decision on whether or not you agree with their argument as a whole. and maybe this forces you to be more honest about what those feelings you have are. and maybe it's also somewhat cowardly? to only want to speak in a setting that allows only you to speak. or, maybe not. i like having conversations with people online, i like hearing peoples' opinions on things. i don't think i don't like real-life arguments because they allow other people to argue with me, i think i just don't like being misrepresented in the heat of the moment, either by myself, or the person i'm arguing with. or maybe that justification is just something i've made up to make myself feel more comfortable about disliking arguing face to face. i don't know. i just think interacting with people in real life is exhausting. i wish there were a way to let people know exactly what i was thinking without having to deal with the social cues about when and how it is acceptable to say what i want to say. and having to find the exact words to say what i mean on the spot. but maybe that's just life. it's certainly a skill i don't have right now anyway what was my question again? oh, whatever, what's your stance on doors

118690.question: So, I know that if you multiply or divide a positive number by a negative number you get a negative number, and if you multiply or divide two negatives, you get a positive.... But I remember learning "that's just how it is", and I can't really conceptionalize what's actually happening there... Can you maybe help me to understand what it means to multiply or divide a number 'a negative amount of times'? Multiplications means "the repeating addition of groups of equal sizes"... So -2 x 3 means that I have three groups of -2 that I am adding together... -2 + -2 + -2, which is -6... And I know that if -2 x 3 = -6, then 3 x -2 must also = -6 (symmetric property or whatever that's called)... But what am I actually doing if I have 3 x -2??? Like what is actually happening to that 3 to get me to -6? 3 x -2 means that I have "negative two groups" of 3 that I am adding together? How can I have "negative two groups" of something? And then why would having "negative two groups" of -3 give me a positive 6? I think I'm confused because negative numbers don't truly exist as quantities. You either have some of something, or you have none of something. There's no such thing as a "negative amount" of something in real life. I can have no (0) hats, or I can have 1 hat, 2 hats, 3 hats, etc. But I can't have a negative amount of hats. So how can I multiply/divide a number by a negative amount of times? In this case, isn't the negative number being used as a quantity?
118690.answer: you add up two negative 3s 2 groups of negative the thing maybe it would help if you thought of 'negative' to mean 'opposite'. going to the opposite side of zero, on the numberline maybe you could think of them as directions. for example, if you go East, negative 10 miles, this means you actually go West 10 miles sure, but you can have a change in the amount of hats, and this number can be positive or negative. if you have 2 hats but you used to have 5, you can say you have negative 3 hats compared to what you had before. you'll also need the negativity concept if you have debt. for example, if you have -3 hats, this means you owe someone some hats, so even if you aquire some hats later you'll have to immediately give them away before you get to keep that 4th one, bringing you to 1 it's more like a direction

118801.question: why are the 4th and 5th called perfect but the 2nd separated into major and minor
118801.answer: i will explain some fun facts for you, and then you will be able to make a lot of sense out of things: if you invert any interval (swap the high and low note), to get the name of the new interval you subtract the number from 9, and for the quality, major becomes minor, minor becomes major, augmented becomes dininished, diminished becomes augmented, and perfect stays perfect. so for example, C to E is a major 3rd, E to C is a minor 6th. C to G# is an augmented 5th, G# to C is a diminished 4th. C to F is a perfect 4th, F to C is a perfect 5th. C to Gb is a diminished 5th, Gb to C is an augmented 4th. if all goes well, this might raise more questions, but then answer even more

118867.question: I have to take a lot of phone calls and listen toa lot of voicemails for my work... and I think it's really funny that whenpeople leave a voicemail, almost everybody starts off by saying 'Yes' or 'Yeah'... like, every voicemail is always "Yes, hello, my name is John and I'm calling about...", or "Yeah, hi, my name is Jane and I was calling to ask if..."... I think it's something about leaving a voicemail that just compels people to start off with "yes" or "yeah" subconsciously??? I can't imagine I'd ever write that in a text message, "Yes, hi, what's going on? Wanna meet up for dinner later?"... Or even saying that in-person would feel silly... like being in the line at the grocery store and saying to the cashier "Yes, hi, have a nice day". Sorry, I don't really have a question. But I just noticed that this was a thing (I think I probably do it too if ever I leave a voicemail), and something about this I find to be very amusing... and I am using this questions page here just to write about my amusement.
118867.answer: the rabbit hole of speaking mannerisms, or for that matter written mannerisms, is perhaps deeper than you ever thought possible

118980.question: you mentioned in an earlier question something along the lines that for the most part, instrumental music tends to be made in service of a video game, movie, etc. but i listen to plenty of instrumental songs made independently from any other media form. i was wondering if most of these songs actually serve the title of the song, which is usually where the idea/message comes from in my experience. then again, there's plenty of cases where the title/message/music dont really line up. could you elaborate more on your thoughts on instrumental vs lyrical music?
118980.answer: ah yes, i was expecting to hear from you i had more examples of things that instrumental music attaches to. but for brevity i only mentioned 2, but yours would have been next on the list. for example: you could be listening to instrumental music produced and delivered as just music, (and not produced as a soundtrack to anything), then, it's likely that you are aware of the identity/persona of the artist, such as name, what instrument they play, and maybe they even have a nice photo of themself on the cover, perhaps with the instrument. as you listen, you are aware of the person, almost like the way a movie star would star in a movie. so in that sense, the artist's persona is what anchors the music. Or, in another case entirely, maybe you are using the music as background music, and in that case it might be part of a broader collection/library of music, maybe even in some context where it doesn't matter who the artist is. In this case, being background music, the anchor element will be whatever you are actually doing in real life. Or, even more enchanting, would be if someone else picked the background music for their own location, in which you are a guest. so if you are in a store and there's music there-- this can enrich and enchant your experience in that location, and, in turn, your experience in that location will help anchor the music. you may even think back on that situation and feel great adoration for that song, meanwhile actually your experience of being in that store will very much help to anchor those feelings. If music actually were not connected or anchored to anything or anyplace in any way, then technically you wouldn't even be able to recall where or when you heard it, and possibly would have no memory of it at all

119397.question: If somebody is upset at me about something that Isaid as a joke, and I genuinely don't feel like I did anything wrong, do I apologize? I feel bad that the person is upset, but I don't feel sorry for what I said. And if I apologize to someone I want it to be a genuine apology and not just "Oh, sorry that you were offended". For context (and this sounds silly in retrospect)... my friend had jellybeans and she said she did not like the black jellybeans and I made a very dumb joke that was "Oh, wow, that's racist" and her response was to get all downtrodden and say "I really don't appreciate you calling me racist. That's not cool."....then the rest of the day she was giving me the cold shoulder... Like,ok, it was a dumb joke. But, obviously (or at least I think it's obvious) I do not actually believe that someone is racist because they don't like black jellybeans. That's (to me) clearly not a serious accusation of racism.

119606.question: oftentimes when im making comics or writing music, i find myself repeatedly and distractingly discontented, frustrated, and agonized over the aesthetic and structure of the english language. i feel like my woes can only be quelled if i invent my own language to do stuff in, but that might take upwards of my whole life. should i go on with making my own language, or should i stop being a baby and just do it all in english?
119606.answer: there is a 3rd option, which is to learn another existing language, for a fresh perspective. it might even spice up your english. doing a conlang will also give you some perspective, now that i think about it. conlangs are totally different from real languages, and it's almost impossible for conlangs to have the natural (and sometimes unexplainable) quirks that develop in real languages. but you might learn something along the way. you might also notice that there is no native speaking audience of your conlang, which may bring you straight back to english. then again you might also notice something similar if you learn a real language with a smaller population of speakers than english. but that will also give you some perspective. either way you will learn something. what the heck, do the whole thing in numbers maybe

119613.question: Probably been asked before, but is there any particular key you keep coming back to? And is there any particular reason for that?
119613.answer: i favor all 12 keys equally EXCEPT possibly C. i don't avoid C too seriously, but i think there is a mild tendency to avoid it because i think on some deep level it probably sounds the most bland because it's the most used by beginners (maybe? probably?). but when C turns out to be the best key for the vocal, i try to remind myself that it's not a crime to be in C. However, i have to also mention the elephant under the rug here, which is that in saying that i prefer these 12 (or 11) keys equally, i'm also saying that i also stick to A=440 tuning. now, in terms of freshness, it would actually be much much better to throw it somewhere else. but on the other hand, the reason i keep it in 440 is as a courtesy to practicing musicians who like to noodle along to their playlist and then get fucked when something like 'beat it' comes on, for example

119615.question: do you have perfect pitch? I feel like you would have it
119615.answer: it's weird that people think that, but it's actually the less musical people who have it. it's the ability to remember absolute pitches non-musically. over the course of my life i've sort of retroactively hacked my brain to be able to do such a such a stunt, but what's far more important than that, for me, is that i have the ability to easily and instantly recognize pitches with perfect musical accuracy. this is ironically not called 'perfect pitch'

119905.question: Is it normal to kinda just feel numb around your friends? I don't mind their company, but I don't really enjoy it. I feel like I suppress my real self so much when I'm at school that I've ended up in a group of friends who I don't feel any real connection with whatsoever, but also im worried that maybe this is just a problem with me and I will never have any "real connections" in my life ever. I've felt this feeling about other friends too. Sorry for dumping this all on you, but I really value your thoughts. Have a good day :)

119937.question: how to know what's going on so i won't make silly mistakes in decision making that i will come to regret? i typically don't know what's happening at least 96% of the time
119937.answer: you can comprimise by dividing up this 96% into two halves. so, 48% of the time, just watch and listen (don't do anything). and the other 48% of the time, try doing something even if you don't know what you're doing. by doing something, you will learn something, and the original 96% (in which you don't know what's happening) will turn into 95%. continue until that gets down to 49%. it doesn't get any lower than that, because no know ever knows what's going on more than 51% of the time
